From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

This article is about GPGPU cards. For the GPU microarchitecture, see [Tesla
(microarchitecture)](/wiki/Tesla_\(microarchitecture\) "Tesla
\(microarchitecture\)").

"Tesla P100" redirects here. For the line of performance cars by Tesla Motors
(P100D), see [Tesla Model S](/wiki/Tesla_Model_S "Tesla Model S") and [Tesla
Model X](/wiki/Tesla_Model_X "Tesla Model X").

Nvidia's line of general purpose GPUs

Nvidia Tesla[![Nvidia Tesla
GPU](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/NvidiaTesla.jpg/300px-
NvidiaTesla.jpg)](/wiki/File:NvidiaTesla.jpg "Nvidia Tesla GPU")  
---  
Manufacturer| [Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia")  
Introduced| May 2, 2007;  
16 years ago (2007-05-02)  
Discontinued| The brand Tesla discontinued on May 2020; 3 years ago (2020-05),
nowadays it's branded as Nvidia Data Center GPUs  
Type| General purpose [graphics cards](/wiki/Graphics_card "Graphics card")  
  
**Nvidia Tesla** is a discontinued line of products developed by
[Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia") targeted at [stream
processing](/wiki/Stream_processing "Stream processing") or [general-purpose
graphics processing units](/wiki/GPGPU "GPGPU") (GPGPU), [named
after](/wiki/Named_after "Named after") pioneering electrical engineer [Nikola
Tesla](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla "Nikola Tesla"). Its products began using GPUs from
the [G80](/wiki/GeForce_8_series "GeForce 8 series") series, and have
continued to accompany the release of new chips. They are programmable using
the [CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") or [OpenCL](/wiki/OpenCL "OpenCL")
[APIs](/wiki/Application_programming_interface "Application programming
interface").

The Nvidia Tesla product line competed with AMD's [Radeon
Instinct](/wiki/Radeon_Instinct "Radeon Instinct") and Intel [Xeon
Phi](/wiki/Xeon_Phi "Xeon Phi") lines of deep learning and GPU cards.

Nvidia retired the Tesla brand in May 2020, reportedly because of potential
confusion with the [brand of cars](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.").[1] Its
new GPUs are branded **Nvidia Data Center GPUs**[2] as in the
[Ampere](/wiki/Ampere_\(microarchitecture\) "Ampere
\(microarchitecture\)")-based A100 GPU.[3]

section: Overview")]

The Nvidia Tesla product line competed with AMD's [Radeon
Instinct](/wiki/Radeon_Instinct "Radeon Instinct") and Intel [Xeon
Phi](/wiki/Xeon_Phi "Xeon Phi") lines of deep learning and GPU cards.

Nvidia retired the Tesla brand in May 2020, reportedly because of potential
confusion with the [brand of cars](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.").[1] Its
new GPUs are branded **Nvidia Data Center GPUs**[2] as in the
[Ampere](/wiki/Ampere_\(microarchitecture\) "Ampere
\(microarchitecture\)")-based A100 GPU.[3]

## Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia_Tesla&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Overview")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/NvidiaTesla2075.JPG/220px-
NvidiaTesla2075.JPG)](/wiki/File:NvidiaTesla2075.JPG)Nvidia Tesla C2075

Offering computational power much greater than traditional
[microprocessors](/wiki/Central_processing_units "Central processing units"),
the Tesla products targeted the [high-performance computing](/wiki/High-
performance_computing "High-performance computing") market.[4] As of
2012[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nvidia_Tesla&action=edit),
Nvidia Teslas power some of the world's fastest
[supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputers "Supercomputers"), including
[Summit](/wiki/Summit_\(supercomputer\) "Summit \(supercomputer\)") at [Oak
Ridge National Laboratory](/wiki/Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory "Oak Ridge
National Laboratory") and [Tianhe-1A](/wiki/Tianhe-1A "Tianhe-1A"), in
[Tianjin](/wiki/Tianjin "Tianjin"), [China](/wiki/China "China").

Tesla cards have four times the double precision performance of a
[Fermi](/wiki/Fermi_\(microarchitecture\) "Fermi \(microarchitecture\)")-based
Nvidia GeForce card of similar single precision performance.[ _[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ] Unlike
Nvidia's consumer [GeForce](/wiki/GeForce "GeForce") cards and professional
[Nvidia Quadro](/wiki/Nvidia_Quadro "Nvidia Quadro") cards, Tesla cards were
originally unable to output images to a [display](/wiki/Computer_monitor
"Computer monitor"). However, the last Tesla C-class products included one
Dual-Link DVI port.[5]

As part of [Project Denver](/wiki/Project_Denver "Project Denver"), Nvidia
intends to embed ARMv8 processor cores in its GPUs.[6] This will be a 64-bit
follow-up to the 32-bit [Tegra](/wiki/Tegra "Tegra") chips.

The Tesla P100 uses [TSMC](/wiki/TSMC "TSMC")'s [16
nanometer](/w/index.php?title=16_nanometer&action=edit&redlink=1 "16 nanometer
\(page does not exist\)") [FinFET](/wiki/FinFET "FinFET") [semiconductor
manufacturing process](/wiki/Semiconductor_manufacturing_process
"Semiconductor manufacturing process"), which is more advanced than the
[28-nanometer](/w/index.php?title=28_nanometer&action=edit&redlink=1 "28
nanometer \(page does not exist\)") process previously used by [AMD](/wiki/AMD
"AMD") and Nvidia GPUs between 2012 and 2016. The P100 also uses
[Samsung](/wiki/Samsung "Samsung")'s [HBM2](/wiki/HBM2 "HBM2") memory.[7]

## Applications[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia_Tesla&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Applications")]

Tesla products are primarily used in simulations and in large-scale
calculations (especially floating-point calculations), and for high-end image
generation for professional and scientific fields.[8]

In 2013, the defense industry accounted for less than one-sixth of Tesla
sales, but Sumit Gupta predicted increasing sales to the [geospatial
intelligence](/wiki/Geospatial_intelligence "Geospatial intelligence")
market.[9]

## Specifications[[edit](/w/index.

The P100 also uses
[Samsung](/wiki/Samsung "Samsung")'s [HBM2](/wiki/HBM2 "HBM2") memory.[7]

**GeForce** is a [brand](/wiki/Brand "Brand") of [graphics processing
units](/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit "Graphics processing unit") (GPUs)
designed by [Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia") and marketed for the performance
market. As of the [GeForce 40 series](/wiki/GeForce_40_series "GeForce 40
series"), there have been eighteen iterations of the design. The first GeForce
products were discrete GPUs designed for add-on graphics boards, intended for
the high-margin PC gaming market, and later diversification of the product
line covered all tiers of the PC graphics market, ranging from cost-
sensitive[1] GPUs integrated on motherboards, to mainstream add-in retail
boards. Most recently,[
_[when?

As of the [GeForce 40 series](/wiki/GeForce_40_series "GeForce 40
series"), there have been eighteen iterations of the design. The first GeForce
products were discrete GPUs designed for add-on graphics boards, intended for
the high-margin PC gaming market, and later diversification of the product
line covered all tiers of the PC graphics market, ranging from cost-
sensitive[1] GPUs integrated on motherboards, to mainstream add-in retail
boards. Most recently,[
_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_ ] GeForce technology has been
introduced into Nvidia's line of embedded application processors, designed for
electronic handhelds and mobile handsets.

With respect to discrete GPUs, found in add-in graphics-boards, Nvidia's
GeForce and [AMD](/wiki/AMD "AMD")'s [Radeon](/wiki/Radeon "Radeon") GPUs are
the only remaining competitors in the high-end market. GeForce GPUs are very
dominant in the [general-purpose graphics processor unit](/wiki/General-
purpose_computing_on_graphics_processing_units "General-purpose computing on
graphics processing units") (GPGPU) market thanks to their proprietary
[Compute Unified Device Architecture](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") (CUDA).[2] GPGPU is
expected to expand GPU functionality beyond the traditional rasterization of
3D graphics, to turn it into a high-performance computing device able to
execute arbitrary programming code in the same way a CPU does, but with
different strengths (highly parallel execution of straightforward
calculations) and weaknesses (worse performance for complex
[branching](/wiki/Branch_\(computer_science\) "Branch \(computer science\)")
code).

## Name origin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Name origin")]

The "GeForce" name originated from a contest held by Nvidia in early 1999
called "Name That Chip". The company called out to the public to name the
successor to the [RIVA TNT2](/wiki/RIVA_TNT2 "RIVA TNT2") line of graphics
boards. There were over 12,000 entries received and 7 winners received a RIVA
TNT2 Ultra graphics card as a reward.[3][4] Brian Burke, senior PR manager at
Nvidia, told _[Maximum PC](/wiki/Maximum_PC "Maximum PC")_ in 2002 that
"GeForce" originally stood for "Geometry Force" since [GeForce
256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce 256") was the first GPU for personal computers
to calculate the [transform-and-
lighting](/wiki/Transform,_clipping,_and_lighting "Transform, clipping, and
lighting") geometry, offloading that function from the
[CPU](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing unit").

The company called out to the public to name the
successor to the [RIVA TNT2](/wiki/RIVA_TNT2 "RIVA TNT2") line of graphics
boards. There were over 12,000 entries received and 7 winners received a RIVA
TNT2 Ultra graphics card as a reward.[3][4] Brian Burke, senior PR manager at
Nvidia, told _[Maximum PC](/wiki/Maximum_PC "Maximum PC")_ in 2002 that
"GeForce" originally stood for "Geometry Force" since [GeForce
256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce 256") was the first GPU for personal computers
to calculate the [transform-and-
lighting](/wiki/Transform,_clipping,_and_lighting "Transform, clipping, and
lighting") geometry, offloading that function from the
[CPU](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing unit").[5]

### GeForce 256[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: GeForce 256")]

Main article: [GeForce 256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce 256")

### GeForce 2 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: GeForce 2 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 2 series](/wiki/GeForce_2_series "GeForce 2 series")

Launched in April 2000, the first GeForce2 (NV15) was another high-performance
graphics chip. Nvidia moved to a twin texture processor per pipeline (4x2)
design, doubling texture fillrate per clock compared to GeForce 256.

Nvidia moved to a twin texture processor per pipeline (4x2)
design, doubling texture fillrate per clock compared to GeForce 256. Later,
Nvidia released the GeForce2 MX (NV11), which offered performance similar to
the GeForce 256 but at a fraction of the cost. The MX was a compelling value
in the low/mid-range market segments and was popular with OEM PC manufacturers
and users alike. The GeForce 2 Ultra was the high-end model in this series.

### GeForce 3 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: GeForce 3 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 3 series](/wiki/GeForce_3_series "GeForce 3 series")

Launched in February 2001, the GeForce3 (NV20) introduced programmable [vertex
and pixel shaders](/wiki/Vertex_and_pixel_shaders "Vertex and pixel shaders")
to the GeForce family and to consumer-level graphics accelerators. It had good
overall performance and shader support, making it popular with enthusiasts
although it never hit the midrange price point. The _NV2A_ developed for the
[Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") [Xbox](/wiki/Xbox_\(console\) "Xbox
\(console\)") game console is a derivative of the GeForce 3.

### GeForce 4 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: GeForce 4 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 4 series](/wiki/GeForce_4_series "GeForce 4 series")

Launched in February 2002, the then-high-end GeForce4 Ti (NV25) was mostly a
refinement to the GeForce3. The biggest advancements included enhancements to
anti-aliasing capabilities, an improved memory controller, a second vertex
shader, and a manufacturing process size reduction to increase clock speeds.
Another member of the GeForce 4 family, the budget GeForce4 MX was based on
the GeForce2, with the addition of some features from the GeForce4 Ti. It
targeted the value segment of the market and lacked pixel shaders. Most of
these models used the [AGP](/wiki/Accelerated_Graphics_Port "Accelerated
Graphics Port") 4× interface, but a few began the transition to AGP 8×.

### GeForce FX series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: GeForce FX series")]

Main article: [GeForce FX series](/wiki/GeForce_FX_series "GeForce FX series")

Launched in 2003, the GeForce FX (NV30) was a huge change in architecture
compared to its predecessors. The GPU was designed not only to support the new
Shader Model 2 specification but also to perform well on older titles.
However, initial models like the GeForce FX 5800 Ultra suffered from weak
[floating point](/wiki/Floating_point "Floating point") shader performance and
excessive heat which required infamously noisy two-slot cooling solutions.
Products in this series carry the 5000 model number, as it is the fifth
generation of the GeForce, though Nvidia marketed the cards as GeForce FX
instead of GeForce 5 to show off "the dawn of cinematic rendering".

### GeForce 6 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: GeForce 6 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 6 series](/wiki/GeForce_6_series "GeForce 6 series")

Launched in April 2004, the GeForce 6 (NV40) added Shader Model 3.0 support to
the GeForce family, while correcting the weak floating point shader
performance of its predecessor. It also implemented [high-dynamic-range
imaging](/wiki/High-dynamic-range_imaging "High-dynamic-range imaging") and
introduced [SLI](/wiki/Scalable_Link_Interface "Scalable Link Interface")
(Scalable Link Interface) and [PureVideo](/wiki/Nvidia_PureVideo "Nvidia
PureVideo") capability (integrated partial hardware MPEG-2, VC-1, Windows
Media Video, and H.264 decoding and fully accelerated video post-processing).

It also implemented [high-dynamic-range
imaging](/wiki/High-dynamic-range_imaging "High-dynamic-range imaging") and
introduced [SLI](/wiki/Scalable_Link_Interface "Scalable Link Interface")
(Scalable Link Interface) and [PureVideo](/wiki/Nvidia_PureVideo "Nvidia
PureVideo") capability (integrated partial hardware MPEG-2, VC-1, Windows
Media Video, and H.264 decoding and fully accelerated video post-processing).

### GeForce 7 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: GeForce 7 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 7 series](/wiki/GeForce_7_series "GeForce 7 series")

The seventh generation GeForce (G70/NV47) was launched in June 2005 and was
the last Nvidia video card series that could support the
[AGP](/wiki/Accelerated_Graphics_Port "Accelerated Graphics Port") bus. The
design was a refined version of GeForce 6, with the major improvements being a
widened pipeline and an increase in clock speed. The GeForce 7 also offers new
transparency [supersampling](/wiki/Supersampling "Supersampling") and
transparency multisampling anti-aliasing modes (TSAA and TMAA). These new
anti-aliasing modes were later enabled for the GeForce 6 series as well. The
GeForce 7950GT featured the highest performance GPU with an AGP interface in
the Nvidia line. This era began the transition to the PCI-Express interface.

A 128-bit, 8 ROP variant of the 7800 GTX, called the [RSX 'Reality
Synthesizer'](/wiki/RSX_%27Reality_Synthesizer%27 "RSX 'Reality
Synthesizer'"), is used as the main GPU in the Sony [PlayStation
3](/wiki/PlayStation_3 "PlayStation 3").

### GeForce 8 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: GeForce 8 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 8 series](/wiki/GeForce_8_series "GeForce 8 series")

Released on November 8, 2006, the eighth-generation GeForce (originally called
G80) was the first ever GPU to fully support [Direct3D](/wiki/Direct3D
"Direct3D") 10\. Manufactured using a 90 nm process and built around the new
[Tesla microarchitecture](/wiki/Tesla_\(microarchitecture\) "Tesla
\(microarchitecture\)"), it implemented the [unified shader
model](/wiki/Unified_shader_model "Unified shader model"). Initially just the
8800GTX model was launched, while the GTS variant was released months into the
product line's life, and it took nearly six months for mid-range and
OEM/mainstream cards to be integrated into the 8 series. The die shrink down
to [65 nm](/wiki/65_nanometer "65 nanometer") and a revision to the G80
design, codenamed G92, were implemented into the 8 series with the 8800GS,
8800GT and 8800GTS-512, first released on October 29, 2007, almost one whole
year after the initial G80 release.

### GeForce 9 series and 100
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section:
GeForce 9 series and 100 series")]

Main articles: [GeForce 9 series](/wiki/GeForce_9_series "GeForce 9 series")
and [GeForce 100 series](/wiki/GeForce_100_series "GeForce 100 series")

The first product was released on February 21, 2008.[6] Not even four months
older than the initial G92 release, all 9-series designs are simply revisions
to existing late 8-series products. The 9800GX2 uses two G92 GPUs, as used in
later 8800 cards, in a dual PCB configuration while still only requiring a
single PCI-Express 16x slot. The 9800GX2 utilizes two separate 256-bit memory
busses, one for each GPU and its respective 512 MB of memory, which equates to
an overall of 1 GB of memory on the card (although the SLI configuration of
the chips necessitates mirroring the frame buffer between the two chips, thus
effectively halving the memory performance of a 256-bit/512MB configuration).

[6] Not even four months
older than the initial G92 release, all 9-series designs are simply revisions
to existing late 8-series products. The 9800GX2 uses two G92 GPUs, as used in
later 8800 cards, in a dual PCB configuration while still only requiring a
single PCI-Express 16x slot. The 9800GX2 utilizes two separate 256-bit memory
busses, one for each GPU and its respective 512 MB of memory, which equates to
an overall of 1 GB of memory on the card (although the SLI configuration of
the chips necessitates mirroring the frame buffer between the two chips, thus
effectively halving the memory performance of a 256-bit/512MB configuration).
The later 9800GTX features a single G92 GPU, 256-bit data bus, and 512 MB of
GDDR3 memory.[7]

Prior to the release, no concrete information was known except that the
officials claimed the next generation products had close to 1 TFLOPS
processing power with the GPU cores still being manufactured in the 65 nm
process, and reports about Nvidia downplaying the significance of
[Direct3D](/wiki/Direct3D "Direct3D") 10.1.[8] In March 2009, several sources
reported that Nvidia had quietly launched a new series of GeForce products,
namely the GeForce 100 Series, which consists of rebadged 9 Series
parts.[9][10][11] GeForce 100 series products were not available for
individual purchase.[1]

### GeForce 200 series and 300
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section:
GeForce 200 series and 300 series")]

Main articles: [GeForce 200 series](/wiki/GeForce_200_series "GeForce 200
series") and [GeForce 300 series](/wiki/GeForce_300_series "GeForce 300
series")

Based on the GT200 graphics processor consisting of 1.4 billion transistors,
codenamed Tesla, the 200 series was launched on June 16, 2008.[12] The next
generation of the GeForce series takes the card-naming scheme in a new
direction, by replacing the series number (such as 8800 for 8-series cards)
with the GTX or GTS suffix (which used to go at the end of card names,
denoting their 'rank' among other similar models), and then adding model-
numbers such as 260 and 280 after that. The series features the new GT200 core
on a [65nm](/wiki/65_nanometer "65 nanometer") die.[13] The first products
were the GeForce GTX 260 and the more expensive GeForce GTX 280.[14] The
GeForce 310 was released on November 27, 2009, which is a rebrand of GeForce
210.[15][16] The 300 series cards are rebranded DirectX 10.1 compatible GPUs
from the 200 series, which were not available for individual purchase.

### GeForce 400 series and 500
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section:
GeForce 400 series and 500 series")]

Main articles: [GeForce 400 series](/wiki/GeForce_400_series "GeForce 400
series") and [GeForce 500 series](/wiki/GeForce_500_series "GeForce 500
series")

On April 7, 2010, Nvidia released[17] the GeForce GTX 470 and GTX 480, the
first cards based on the [new Fermi
architecture](/wiki/Fermi_\(microarchitecture\) "Fermi
\(microarchitecture\)"), codenamed GF100; they were the first Nvidia GPUs to
utilize 1 GB or more of [GDDR5](/wiki/GDDR5 "GDDR5") memory. The GTX 470 and
GTX 480 were heavily criticized due to high power use, high temperatures, and
very loud noise that were not balanced by the performance offered, even though
the GTX 480 was the fastest DirectX 11 card as of its introduction.

In November 2010, Nvidia released a new flagship GPU based on an enhanced
GF100 architecture (GF110) called the GTX 580. It featured higher performance,
less power utilization, heat and noise than the preceding GTX 480. This GPU
received much better reviews than the GTX 480. Nvidia later also released the
GTX 590, which packs two GF110 GPUs on a single card.

The GTX 470 and
GTX 480 were heavily criticized due to high power use, high temperatures, and
very loud noise that were not balanced by the performance offered, even though
the GTX 480 was the fastest DirectX 11 card as of its introduction.

In November 2010, Nvidia released a new flagship GPU based on an enhanced
GF100 architecture (GF110) called the GTX 580. It featured higher performance,
less power utilization, heat and noise than the preceding GTX 480. This GPU
received much better reviews than the GTX 480. Nvidia later also released the
GTX 590, which packs two GF110 GPUs on a single card.

### GeForce 600 series, 700 series and 800M
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section:
GeForce 600 series, 700 series and 800M series")]

Main articles: [GeForce 600 series](/wiki/GeForce_600_series "GeForce 600
series"), [GeForce 700 series](/wiki/GeForce_700_series "GeForce 700 series"),
and [GeForce 800M series](/wiki/GeForce_800M_series "GeForce 800M series")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/ASUS_GTX-650_Ti_TOP_Cu-
II_PCI_Express_3.0_x16_graphics_card.jpg/220px-ASUS_GTX-650_Ti_TOP_Cu-
II_PCI_Express_3.0_x16_graphics_card.jpg)](/wiki/File:ASUS_GTX-650_Ti_TOP_Cu-
II_PCI_Express_3.0_x16_graphics_card.jpg)[Asus](/wiki/Asus "Asus") Nvidia
GeForce GTX 650 Ti, a PCI Express 3.0 ×16 graphics card

In September 2010, Nvidia announced that the successor to [Fermi
microarchitecture](/wiki/Fermi_\(microarchitecture\) "Fermi
\(microarchitecture\)") would be the [Kepler
microarchitecture](/wiki/Kepler_\(microarchitecture\) "Kepler
\(microarchitecture\)"), manufactured with the TSMC 28 nm fabrication process.
Earlier, Nvidia had been contracted to supply their top-end GK110 cores for
use in [Oak Ridge National Laboratory](/wiki/Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory
"Oak Ridge National Laboratory")'s ["Titan"
supercomputer](/wiki/Titan_\(supercomputer\) "Titan \(supercomputer\)"),
leading to a shortage of GK110 cores. After AMD launched their own annual
refresh in early 2012, the Radeon HD 7000 series, Nvidia began the release of
the GeForce 600 series in March 2012. The GK104 core, originally intended for
their mid-range segment of their lineup, became the flagship GTX 680\. It
introduced significant improvements in performance, heat, and power efficiency
compared to the Fermi architecture and closely matched AMD's flagship Radeon
HD 7970. It was quickly followed by the dual-GK104 GTX 690 and the GTX 670,
which featured only a slightly cut-down GK104 core and was very close in
performance to the GTX 680\.

With the GTX Titan, Nvidia also released GPU Boost 2.0, which would allow the
GPU clock speed to increase indefinitely until a user-set temperature limit
was reached without passing a user-specified maximum fan speed. The final
GeForce 600 series release was the GTX 650 Ti BOOST based on the GK106 core,
in response to AMD's Radeon HD 7790 release. At the end of May 2013, Nvidia
announced the 700 series, which was still based on the Kepler architecture,
however it featured a GK110-based card at the top of the lineup. The GTX 780
was a slightly cut-down Titan that achieved nearly the same performance for
two-thirds of the price. It featured the same advanced reference cooler
design, but did not have the unlocked double-precision cores and was equipped
with 3 GB of memory.

At the same time, Nvidia announced [ShadowPlay](/wiki/Nvidia_Shadowplay
"Nvidia Shadowplay"), a screen capture solution that used an integrated H.264
encoder built into the Kepler architecture that Nvidia had not revealed
previously. It could be used to record gameplay without a capture card, and
with negligible performance decrease compared to software recording solutions,
and was available even on the previous generation GeForce 600 series cards.
The software beta for ShadowPlay, however, experienced multiple delays and
would not be released until the end of October 2013.

The GTX 780
was a slightly cut-down Titan that achieved nearly the same performance for
two-thirds of the price. It featured the same advanced reference cooler
design, but did not have the unlocked double-precision cores and was equipped
with 3 GB of memory.

At the same time, Nvidia announced [ShadowPlay](/wiki/Nvidia_Shadowplay
"Nvidia Shadowplay"), a screen capture solution that used an integrated H.264
encoder built into the Kepler architecture that Nvidia had not revealed
previously. It could be used to record gameplay without a capture card, and
with negligible performance decrease compared to software recording solutions,
and was available even on the previous generation GeForce 600 series cards.
The software beta for ShadowPlay, however, experienced multiple delays and
would not be released until the end of October 2013. A week after the release
of the GTX 780, Nvidia announced the GTX 770 to be a rebrand of the GTX 680\.
It was followed by the GTX 760 shortly after, which was also based on the
GK104 core and similar to the GTX 660 Ti. No more 700 series cards were set
for release in 2013, although Nvidia announced G-Sync, another feature of the
Kepler architecture that Nvidia had left unmentioned, which allowed the GPU to
dynamically control the refresh rate of G-Sync-compatible monitors which would
release in 2014, to combat tearing and judder. However, in October, AMD
released the R9 290X, which came in at $100 less than the GTX 780\. In
response, Nvidia slashed the price of the GTX 780 by $150 and released the GTX
780 Ti, which featured a full 2880-core GK110 core even more powerful than the
GTX Titan, along with enhancements to the power delivery system which improved
overclocking, and managed to pull ahead of AMD's new release.

The GeForce 800M series consists of rebranded 700M series parts based on the
Kepler architecture and some lower-end parts based on the newer Maxwell
architecture.

### GeForce 900
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section:
GeForce 900 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 900 series](/wiki/GeForce_900_series "GeForce 900
series")

In March 2013, Nvidia announced that the successor to Kepler would be the
[Maxwell microarchitecture](/wiki/Maxwell_\(microarchitecture\) "Maxwell
\(microarchitecture\)"). It was released in September 2014, with the GM10x
series chips, emphasizing the new power efficiency architectural improvements
in [OEM](/wiki/Original_equipment_manufacturer "Original equipment
manufacturer"), and low [TDP](/wiki/Thermal_design_power "Thermal design
power") products in [desktop](/wiki/Desktop_computer "Desktop computer") GTX
750/750 ti, and mobile GTX 850M/860M. Later that year Nvidia pushed the TDP
with the GM20x chips for power users, skipping the 800 series for desktop
entirely, with the 900 series of GPUs.

This was the last GeForce series to support analog video output through
[DVI-I](/wiki/DVI-I "DVI-I"). Although, analog display adapters exist and are
able to convert a digital [Display Port](/wiki/DisplayPort "DisplayPort"),
[HDMI](/wiki/HDMI "HDMI"), or [DVI-D](/wiki/DVI-D "DVI-D") (Digital).

###  GeForce 10
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section:
GeForce 10 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 10 series](/wiki/GeForce_10_series "GeForce 10 series")

In March 2014, Nvidia announced that the successor to Maxwell would be the
[Pascal microarchitecture](/wiki/Pascal_\(microarchitecture\) "Pascal
\(microarchitecture\)"); announced on 6 May 2016 and released on 27 May 2016.
Architectural improvements include the following:[18][19]

  * In Pascal, an SM (streaming multiprocessor) consists of 128 CUDA cores. Kepler packed 192, Fermi 32 and Tesla only 8 CUDA cores into an SM; the GP100 SM is partitioned into two processing blocks, each having 32 single-precision CUDA Cores, an instruction buffer, a warp scheduler, 2 texture mapping units and 2 dispatch units.

Architectural improvements include the following:[18][19]

  * In Pascal, an SM (streaming multiprocessor) consists of 128 CUDA cores. Kepler packed 192, Fermi 32 and Tesla only 8 CUDA cores into an SM; the GP100 SM is partitioned into two processing blocks, each having 32 single-precision CUDA Cores, an instruction buffer, a warp scheduler, 2 texture mapping units and 2 dispatch units.
  * [GDDR5X](/wiki/GDDR5_SDRAM#GDDR5X "GDDR5 SDRAM") - New memory standard supporting 10Gbit/s data rates and an updated memory controller. Only the Nvidia Titan X (and Titan Xp), GTX 1080, GTX 1080 Ti, and GTX 1060 (6 GB Version) support GDDR5X. The GTX 1070 Ti, GTX 1070, GTX 1060 (3GB version), GTX 1050 Ti, and GTX 1050 use GDDR5.[20]
  * Unified memory - A memory architecture, where the CPU and GPU can access both main system memory and memory on the graphics card with the help of a technology called "Page Migration Engine".
  * [NVLink](/wiki/NVLink "NVLink") - A high-bandwidth bus between the CPU and GPU, and between multiple GPUs. Allows much higher transfer speeds than those achievable by using PCI Express; estimated to provide between 80 and 200 GB/s.[21][22]
  * 16-bit ([FP16](/wiki/Half-precision_floating-point_format "Half-precision floating-point format")) floating-point operations can be executed at twice the rate of 32-bit floating-point operations ("single precision")[23] and 64-bit floating-point operations ("double precision") executed at half the rate of 32-bit floating point operations (Maxwell 1/32 rate).[24]
  * More advanced process node, TSMC [12 nm](/wiki/14_nm_process "14 nm process") instead of the older TSMC [28 nm](/wiki/32_nm_process "32 nm process")

### GeForce 20 series and 16
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section:
GeForce 20 series and 16 series")]

Main articles: [GeForce 20 series](/wiki/GeForce_20_series "GeForce 20
series") and [GeForce 16 series](/wiki/GeForce_16_series "GeForce 16 series")

In August 2018, Nvidia announced the GeForce successor to Pascal. The new
microarchitecture name was revealed as
"[Turing](/wiki/Turing_\(microarchitecture\) "Turing \(microarchitecture\)")"
at the Siggraph 2018 conference.[25] This new GPU microarchitecture is aimed
to accelerate the real-time [ray tracing](/wiki/Ray_tracing_\(graphics\) "Ray
tracing \(graphics\)") support and AI Inferencing. It features a new Ray
Tracing unit (RT Core) which can dedicate processors to the ray tracing in
hardware. It supports the [DXR](/wiki/DirectX_Raytracing "DirectX Raytracing")
extension in Microsoft DirectX 12. Nvidia claims the new architecture is up to
6 times faster than the older Pascal architecture.[26][27] A whole new Tensor
core design since [Volta](/wiki/Volta_\(microarchitecture\) "Volta
\(microarchitecture\)") introduces AI deep learning acceleration, which allows
the utilisation of DLSS ([Deep Learning Super
Sampling](/wiki/Deep_Learning_Super_Sampling "Deep Learning Super Sampling")),
a new form of anti-aliasing that uses AI to provide crisper imagery with less
impact on performance.[28] It also changes its integer execution unit which
can execute in parallel with the floating point data path. A new unified cache
architecture which doubles its bandwidth compared with previous generations
was also announced.[29]

The new GPUs were revealed as the Quadro RTX 8000, Quadro RTX 6000 and Quadro
RTX 5000. The high end Quadro RTX 8000 features 4,608 CUDA cores and 576
Tensor cores with 48GB of VRAM.[26] Later during the [Gamescom](/wiki/Gamescom
"Gamescom") press conference, Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang, unveiled the new
GeForce RTX series with RTX 2080 Ti, 2080, and 2070 that will use the Turing
architecture. The first Turing cards were slated to ship to consumers on
September 20, 2018.

[28] It also changes its integer execution unit which
can execute in parallel with the floating point data path. A new unified cache
architecture which doubles its bandwidth compared with previous generations
was also announced.[29]

The new GPUs were revealed as the Quadro RTX 8000, Quadro RTX 6000 and Quadro
RTX 5000. The high end Quadro RTX 8000 features 4,608 CUDA cores and 576
Tensor cores with 48GB of VRAM.[26] Later during the [Gamescom](/wiki/Gamescom
"Gamescom") press conference, Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang, unveiled the new
GeForce RTX series with RTX 2080 Ti, 2080, and 2070 that will use the Turing
architecture. The first Turing cards were slated to ship to consumers on
September 20, 2018.[30] Nvidia announced the RTX 2060 on January 6, 2019, at
CES 2019.[31]

On July 2, 2019, Nvidia announced the GeForce RTX Super line of cards, a 20
series refresh which comprises higher-spec versions of the RTX 2060, 2070 and
2080. The RTX 2070 and 2080 were discontinued.

In February 2019, Nvidia announced the [GeForce 16
series](/wiki/GeForce_16_series "GeForce 16 series"). It is based on the same
Turing architecture used in the GeForce 20 series, but disabling the Tensor
([AI](/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence")) and RT ([ray
tracing](/wiki/Ray_tracing_\(graphics\) "Ray tracing \(graphics\)")) cores to
provide more affordable graphic cards for gamers while still attaining a
higher performance compared to respective cards of the previous GeForce
generations.

Like the RTX Super refresh, Nvidia on October 29, 2019, announced the GTX 1650
Super and 1660 Super cards, which replaced their non-Super counterparts.

On June 28, 2022, Nvidia quietly released their GTX 1630 card, which was meant
for low-end gamers.

### GeForce 30 series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: GeForce 30 series")]

Main article: [GeForce 30 series](/wiki/GeForce_30_series "GeForce 30 series")

Nvidia officially announced at the GeForce Special Event that the successor to
GeForce 20 series will be the 30 series, it is built on the
[Ampere](/wiki/Ampere_\(microarchitecture\) "Ampere \(microarchitecture\)")
microarchitecture. The GeForce Special Event introduced took place on
September 1, 2020, and set September 17th as the official release date for the
RTX 3080 GPU, September 24th for the RTX 3090 GPU and October 29th for the RTX
3070 GPU.[32][33] With the latest GPU launch being the RTX 3090 Ti. The RTX
3090 Ti is the highest-end Nvidia GPU on the Ampere microarchitecture, it
features a fully unlocked GA102 die built on the Samsung [8
nm](/wiki/7_nm_process "7 nm process") node due to supply shortages with
[TSMC](/wiki/TSMC "TSMC"). The RTX 3090 Ti has 10,752 CUDA cores, 336 Tensor
cores and texture mapping units, 112 ROPs, 84 RT cores, and 24 gigabytes of
[GDDR6X](/wiki/GDDR6_SDRAM "GDDR6 SDRAM") memory with a 384-bit bus.[34] When
compared to the RTX 2080 Ti, the 3090 Ti has 6,400 more CUDA cores. Due to the
[global chip shortage](/wiki/2020%E2%80%93present_global_chip_shortage
"2020–present global chip shortage"), the 30 series was controversial as
scalpers and high demand meant that GPU prices skyrocketed for the 30 series
and the [AMD](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced Micro Devices") [RX
6000](/wiki/Radeon_RX_6000_series "Radeon RX 6000 series") series.

compared to the RTX 2080 Ti, the 3090 Ti has 6,400 more CUDA cores. Due to the
[global chip shortage](/wiki/2020%E2%80%93present_global_chip_shortage
"2020–present global chip shortage"), the 30 series was controversial as
scalpers and high demand meant that GPU prices skyrocketed for the 30 series
and the [AMD](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced Micro Devices") [RX
6000](/wiki/Radeon_RX_6000_series "Radeon RX 6000 series") series.

### GeForce 40 series
(Current)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: GeForce 40 series \(Current\)")]

Main article: [GeForce 40 series](/wiki/GeForce_40_series "GeForce 40 series")

On September 20, 2022, Nvidia announced its GeForce 40 Series graphics
cards.[35] These came out as the RTX 4090, on October 12, 2022, the RTX 4080,
on November 16, 2022, the RTX 4070 Ti, on January 3, 2023, with the RTX 4070,
on April 13, 2023, and the RTX 4060 Ti on May 24, 2023, and the RTX 4060,
following in July of this year. More 40-series are due in 2024, such as the
RTX 4050. These are built on the [Ada
Lovelace](/wiki/Ada_Lovelace_\(microarchitecture\) "Ada Lovelace
\(microarchitecture\)") architecture, with current part numbers being,
"AD102", "AD103", "AD104" "AD106" and "AD107". These parts are manufactured
using the TSMC N4 process node which is a custom-designed process for Nvidia.
The RTX 4090 is currently the fastest chip for the mainstream market that has
been released by a major company, consisting of around 16,384
[CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") cores, boost clocks of 2.2 / 2.5 GHz, 24 GB of
[GDDR6X](/wiki/GDDR6_SDRAM "GDDR6 SDRAM"), a 384-bit memory bus, 128 3rd gen
[RT](/wiki/Ray_tracing_\(graphics\) "Ray tracing \(graphics\)") cores, 512 4th
gen [Tensor](/wiki/Deep_learning_super_sampling "Deep learning super
sampling") cores, [DLSS 3.0](/wiki/Deep_learning_super_sampling "Deep learning
super sampling") and a TDP of 450W.[36]

## Variants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Variants")]

### Mobile GPUs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Mobile GPUs")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/HP_Pavilion_dv9000_motherboard_%283%29.jpg/200px-
HP_Pavilion_dv9000_motherboard_%283%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:HP_Pavilion_dv9000_motherboard_\(3\).jpg)A
Nvidia GeForce Go 7600 integrated on a laptop motherboard[37]

Since the GeForce 2 series, Nvidia has produced a number of graphics chipsets
for notebook computers under the _GeForce Go_ branding. Most of the features
present in the desktop counterparts are present in the mobile ones. These GPUs
are generally optimized for lower power consumption and less heat output in
order to be used in notebook PCs and small desktops.

Beginning with the GeForce 8 series, the _GeForce Go_ brand was discontinued
and the mobile GPUs were integrated with the main line of GeForce GPUs, but
their name suffixed with an _M_. This ended in 2016 with the launch of the
laptop GeForce 10 series – Nvidia dropped the _M_ suffix, opting to unify the
branding between their desktop and laptop GPU offerings, as notebook Pascal
GPUs are almost as powerful as their desktop counterparts (something Nvidia
tested with their "desktop-class" notebook GTX 980 GPU back in 2015).[38]

The _GeForce MX_ brand, previously used by Nvidia for their entry-level
desktop GPUs, was revived in 2017 with the release of the GeForce MX150 for
notebooks.

These GPUs
are generally optimized for lower power consumption and less heat output in
order to be used in notebook PCs and small desktops.

Beginning with the GeForce 8 series, the _GeForce Go_ brand was discontinued
and the mobile GPUs were integrated with the main line of GeForce GPUs, but
their name suffixed with an _M_. This ended in 2016 with the launch of the
laptop GeForce 10 series – Nvidia dropped the _M_ suffix, opting to unify the
branding between their desktop and laptop GPU offerings, as notebook Pascal
GPUs are almost as powerful as their desktop counterparts (something Nvidia
tested with their "desktop-class" notebook GTX 980 GPU back in 2015).[38]

The _GeForce MX_ brand, previously used by Nvidia for their entry-level
desktop GPUs, was revived in 2017 with the release of the GeForce MX150 for
notebooks.[39] The MX150 is based on the same
[Pascal](/wiki/Pascal_\(microarchitecture\) "Pascal \(microarchitecture\)")
GP108 GPU as used on the desktop GT 1030,[40] and was quietly released in June
2017.[39]

### Small form factor
GPUs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section:
Small form factor GPUs")]

Similar to the mobile GPUs, Nvidia also released a few GPUs in "small form
factor" format, for use in all-in-one desktops. These GPUs are suffixed with
an _S_ , similar to the _M_ used for mobile products.[41]

### Integrated desktop motherboard
GPUs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section:
Integrated desktop motherboard GPUs")]

Beginning with the [nForce 4](/wiki/NForce_4 "NForce 4"), Nvidia started
including onboard graphics solutions in their motherboard chipsets. These
onboard graphics solutions were called mGPUs (motherboard GPUs).[42] Nvidia
discontinued the nForce range, including these mGPUs, in 2009.[43]

After the nForce range was discontinued, Nvidia released their
[Ion](/wiki/Nvidia_Ion "Nvidia Ion") line in 2009, which consisted of an
[Intel Atom](/wiki/Intel_Atom "Intel Atom") CPU partnered with a low-end
GeForce 9 series GPU, fixed on the motherboard. Nvidia released an upgraded
_Ion 2_ in 2010, this time containing a low-end GeForce 300 series GPU.

## Nomenclature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Nomenclature")]

From the GeForce 4 series until the GeForce 9 series, the naming scheme below
is used.

## Graphics device
drivers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Graphics device drivers")]

### Official
proprietary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Official proprietary")]

Nvidia develops and publishes GeForce drivers for [Windows
10](/wiki/Windows_10 "Windows 10") [x86](/wiki/X86
"X86")/[x86-64](/wiki/X86-64 "X86-64") and later, [Linux](/wiki/Linux "Linux")
x86/x86-64/[ARMv7-A](/wiki/ARMv7-A "ARMv7-A"), [OS X
10.5](/wiki/Mac_OS_X_Leopard "Mac OS X Leopard") and later,
[Solaris](/wiki/Solaris_\(operating_system\) "Solaris \(operating system\)")
x86/x86-64 and [FreeBSD](/wiki/FreeBSD "FreeBSD") x86/x86-64.[45] A current
version can be downloaded from Nvidia and most Linux distributions contain it
in their own repositories. Nvidia GeForce driver 340.24 from 8 July 2014
supports the [EGL](/wiki/EGL_\(API\) "EGL \(API\)") interface enabling support
for [Wayland](/wiki/Wayland_\(display_server_protocol\) "Wayland \(display
server protocol\)") in conjunction with this driver.[46][47] This may be
different for the [Nvidia Quadro](/wiki/Nvidia_Quadro "Nvidia Quadro") brand,
which is based on identical hardware but features OpenGL-certified graphics
device drivers. On the same day the [Vulkan](/wiki/Vulkan_\(API\) "Vulkan
\(API\)") graphics API was publicly released, Nvidia released drivers that
fully supported it.[48] Nvidia has released drivers with optimizations for
specific video games concurrent with their release since 2014, having released
150 drivers supporting 400 games in April 2022.

[46][47] This may be
different for the [Nvidia Quadro](/wiki/Nvidia_Quadro "Nvidia Quadro") brand,
which is based on identical hardware but features OpenGL-certified graphics
device drivers. On the same day the [Vulkan](/wiki/Vulkan_\(API\) "Vulkan
\(API\)") graphics API was publicly released, Nvidia released drivers that
fully supported it.[48] Nvidia has released drivers with optimizations for
specific video games concurrent with their release since 2014, having released
150 drivers supporting 400 games in April 2022.[49]

Basic support for the [DRM mode-setting
interface](/wiki/Direct_Rendering_Manager#Kernel_mode_setting "Direct
Rendering Manager") in the form of a new kernel module named `nvidia-
modeset.ko` has been available since version 358.09 beta.[50] The support of
Nvidia's [display controller](/wiki/Display_controller "Display controller")
on the supported GPUs is centralized in `nvidia-modeset.ko`. Traditional
display interactions (X11 modesets, OpenGL SwapBuffers, VDPAU presentation,
SLI, stereo, framelock, [G-Sync](/wiki/Nvidia_G-Sync "Nvidia G-Sync"), etc.)
initiate from the various user-mode driver components and flow to `nvidia-
modeset.ko`.[51]

In May 2022, Nvidia announced that it would release a partially open-source
driver for the (GSP enabled) [Turing](/wiki/Turing_\(microarchitecture\)
"Turing \(microarchitecture\)") architecture and newer, in order to enhance
the ability for it to be packaged as part of Linux distributions. At launch
Nvidia considered the driver to be alpha quality for consumer GPUs, and
production ready for datacenter GPUs. Currently the userspace components of
the driver (including OpenGL, Vulkan, and CUDA) remain proprietary. In
addition, the open-source components of the driver are only a wrapper (CPU-
RM[a]) for the GPU System Processor (GSP) firmware, a RISC-V [binary
blob](/wiki/Binary_blob "Binary blob") that is now required for running the
open-source driver.[52][53] The GPU System Processor is a
[RISC-V](/wiki/RISC-V "RISC-V") coprocessor codenamed "Falcon" that is used to
offload GPU initialization and management tasks. The driver itself is still
split for the host CPU portion (CPU-RM[a]) and the GSP portion (GSP-
RM[a]).[54] Windows 11 and Linux propriatery drivers also support enabling GSP
and make even gaming faster.[55][56] [CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") supports GSP
since version 11.6.[57] Upcoming Linux kernel 6.7 will support GSP in
[Nouveau](/wiki/Nouveau_\(software\) "Nouveau \(software\)").[58][59]

### Third-party free and open-
source[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section:
Third-party free and open-source")]

See also: [Free and open-source graphics device driver §
Nvidia](/wiki/Free_and_open-source_graphics_device_driver#Nvidia "Free and
open-source graphics device driver")

Community-created, free and open-source drivers exist as an alternative to the
drivers released by Nvidia. Open-source drivers are developed primarily for
Linux, however there may be ports to other operating systems. The most
prominent alternative driver is the [reverse-
engineered](/wiki/Reverse_engineering "Reverse engineering") free and open-
source _[nouveau](/wiki/Nouveau_\(software\) "Nouveau \(software\)")_ graphics
device driver. Nvidia has publicly announced to not provide any support for
such additional device drivers for their products,[60] although Nvidia has
contributed code to the Nouveau driver.[61]

Free and open-source drivers support a large portion (but not all) of the
features available in GeForce-branded cards. For example, as of January
2014[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit)
nouveau driver lacks support for the GPU and memory clock frequency
adjustments, and for associated dynamic power management.[62] Also, Nvidia's
proprietary drivers consistently perform better than nouveau in various
benchmarks.

The most
prominent alternative driver is the [reverse-
engineered](/wiki/Reverse_engineering "Reverse engineering") free and open-
source _[nouveau](/wiki/Nouveau_\(software\) "Nouveau \(software\)")_ graphics
device driver. Nvidia has publicly announced to not provide any support for
such additional device drivers for their products,[60] although Nvidia has
contributed code to the Nouveau driver.[61]

Free and open-source drivers support a large portion (but not all) of the
features available in GeForce-branded cards. For example, as of January
2014[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit)
nouveau driver lacks support for the GPU and memory clock frequency
adjustments, and for associated dynamic power management.[62] Also, Nvidia's
proprietary drivers consistently perform better than nouveau in various
benchmarks.[63] However, as of August
2014[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit)
and version 3.16 of the [Linux kernel mainline](/wiki/Linux_kernel_mainline
"Linux kernel mainline"), contributions by Nvidia allowed partial support for
GPU and memory clock frequency adjustments to be implemented.[ _[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ]

### Licensing and privacy
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section:
Licensing and privacy issues")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-
Ambox_important.svg.png)

|

This section **possibly contains[original
research](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original
research")**. Please [improve
it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit) by
[verifying](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability") the
claims made and adding [inline
citations](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations "Wikipedia:Citing
sources"). Statements consisting only of original research should be removed.
_( May 2022)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template
message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template
removal"))_  
  
---|---  
  
The license has common terms against reverse engineering and copying, and it
disclaims warranties and liability.[64][ _[original
research?](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original
research")_ ]

Starting in 2016 the GeFORCE license says Nvidia "SOFTWARE may access, collect
non-personally identifiable information about, update, and configure
Customer's system in order to properly optimize such system for use with the
SOFTWARE."[64] The privacy notice goes on to say, "We are not able to respond
to "Do Not Track" signals set by a browser at this time. We also permit third
party online advertising networks and social media companies to collect
information... We may combine personal information that we collect about you
with the browsing and tracking information collected by these [cookies and
beacons] technologies."[65]

The software configures the user's system to optimize its use, and the license
says, "NVIDIA will have no responsibility for any damage or loss to such
system (including loss of data or access) arising from or relating to (a) any
changes to the configuration, application settings, environment variables,
registry, drivers, [BIOS](/wiki/BIOS "BIOS"), or other attributes of the
system (or any part of such system) initiated through the SOFTWARE".[64]

### GeForce
Experience[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: GeForce Experience")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-
Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)|

This section **needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to
it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=GeForce&action=edit&section=).
_( April 2022)_  
  
---|---  
  
GeForce Experience is a program containing several tools including [Nvidia
ShadowPlay](/wiki/Nvidia_ShadowPlay "Nvidia ShadowPlay").[66]

Due to a serious [security
vulnerability](https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2019-5674) before the
March 26, 2019 security update, users of GeForce Experience were vulnerable to
remote [code execution](/wiki/Arbitrary_code_execution "Arbitrary code
execution"), [denial of service](/wiki/Denial-of-service_attack "Denial-of-
service attack"), and [privilege escalation](/wiki/Privilege_escalation
"Privilege escalation") attacks.[67] When installing new drivers, GeForce
Experience may force the system to restart after a 60-second countdown,
without giving the user any choice.

 **Footnotes / references**  
[1][2]  
  
**Nvidia Corporation**[note 1][note 2] ([/ɛnˈvɪdiə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"), [_en- VID-ee-ə_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key
"Help:Pronunciation respelling key")) is an American [multinational
corporation](/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation") and
[technology company](/wiki/Technology_company "Technology company")
headquartered in [Santa Clara, California](/wiki/Santa_Clara,_California
"Santa Clara, California"), and [incorporated in
Delaware](/wiki/Delaware_General_Corporation_Law "Delaware General Corporation
Law").[3] It is a [software](/wiki/Software_company "Software company") and
[fabless](/wiki/Fabless_manufacturing "Fabless manufacturing") company which
designs and supplies [graphics processing
units](/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit "Graphics processing unit") (GPUs),
[application programming interfaces](/wiki/Application_programming_interface
"Application programming interface") (APIs) for [data
science](/wiki/Data_science "Data science") and [high-performance
computing](/wiki/High-performance_computing "High-performance computing") as
well as [system on a chip](/wiki/System_on_a_chip "System on a chip") units
(SoCs) for the [mobile computing](/wiki/Mobile_computing "Mobile computing")
and automotive market. Nvidia is also a
[dominant](/wiki/Dominance_\(economics\) "Dominance \(economics\)") supplier
of [artificial intelligence](/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial
intelligence") (AI) hardware and software.[4][5][6]

Nvidia's professional line of GPUs are used for [edge-to-
cloud](/wiki/Edge_computing "Edge computing") computing and in
[supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputers "Supercomputers") and
[workstations](/wiki/Workstations "Workstations") for applications in such
fields as architecture, engineering and construction, media and entertainment,
automotive, scientific research, and manufacturing design.

Nvidia is also a
[dominant](/wiki/Dominance_\(economics\) "Dominance \(economics\)") supplier
of [artificial intelligence](/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial
intelligence") (AI) hardware and software.[4][5][6]

Nvidia's professional line of GPUs are used for [edge-to-
cloud](/wiki/Edge_computing "Edge computing") computing and in
[supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputers "Supercomputers") and
[workstations](/wiki/Workstations "Workstations") for applications in such
fields as architecture, engineering and construction, media and entertainment,
automotive, scientific research, and manufacturing design.[7] Its
[GeForce](/wiki/GeForce "GeForce") line of GPUs are aimed at the consumer
market and are used in applications such as [video
editing](/wiki/Video_editing "Video editing"), [3D
rendering](/wiki/3D_rendering "3D rendering") and [PC gaming](/wiki/PC_gaming
"PC gaming"). The company expanded its presence in the [gaming
industry](/wiki/Video_game_industry "Video game industry") with the
introduction of the [Shield Portable](/wiki/Nvidia_Shield_Portable "Nvidia
Shield Portable") (a [handheld game console](/wiki/Handheld_game_console
"Handheld game console")), [Shield Tablet](/wiki/Nvidia_Shield_Tablet "Nvidia
Shield Tablet") (a [gaming tablet](/wiki/Gaming_tablet "Gaming tablet")) and
[Shield TV](/wiki/Nvidia_Shield_TV "Nvidia Shield TV") (a [digital media
player](/wiki/Digital_media_player "Digital media player")), as well as its
[cloud gaming](/wiki/Cloud_gaming "Cloud gaming") service [GeForce
Now](/wiki/GeForce_Now "GeForce Now").[8]

In addition to GPU manufacturing, Nvidia provides an API called
[CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") that allows the creation of massively [parallel
programs](/wiki/Parallel_computing "Parallel computing") which utilize
GPUs.[9][10] They are deployed in supercomputing sites around the
world.[11][12] In the late 2000s, Nvidia had moved into the mobile computing
market, where it produces [Tegra](/wiki/Tegra "Tegra") mobile processors for
smartphones and tablets as well as vehicle navigation and entertainment
systems.[13][14][15] Its competitors include [AMD](/wiki/AMD "AMD"),
[Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel"),[16] [Qualcomm](/wiki/Qualcomm "Qualcomm")[17]
and [AI accelerator](/wiki/AI_accelerator "AI accelerator") companies such as
[Cerebras](/wiki/Cerebras "Cerebras") and [Graphcore](/wiki/Graphcore
"Graphcore"). It also makes AI-powered software for audio and video
processing, e.g. Nvidia Maxine.[18]

Nvidia's offer to acquire [Arm](/wiki/Arm_\(company\) "Arm \(company\)") from
[SoftBank](/wiki/SoftBank_Group "SoftBank Group") in September 2020 failed to
materialize following extended regulatory scrutiny, leading to the termination
of the deal in February 2022 in what would have been the largest semiconductor
acquisition.[19][20] In 2023, Nvidia became the seventh public U.S. company to
be [valued at over $1 trillion](/wiki/Trillion_dollar_company "Trillion dollar
company"),[21] and, as of March 2024, it is the world's [third most-valuable
company](/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization "List of
public corporations by market capitalization"), with a [market
capitalization](/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization") of over
$2 trillion.[22]

in 2017. [Apple Park](/wiki/Apple_Park "Apple Park") is visible in the
distance.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/NVIDIA_Headquarters.jpg/220px-
NVIDIA_Headquarters.jpg)](/wiki/File:NVIDIA_Headquarters.jpg)Entrance of
Endeavor headquarters building in 2018

Nvidia was founded on April 5, 1993,[23][24][25] by [Jensen
Huang](/wiki/Jensen_Huang "Jensen Huang") (CEO as of
2024[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit)),
a [Taiwanese-American](/wiki/Taiwanese-American "Taiwanese-American")
[electrical engineer](/wiki/Electrical_engineer "Electrical engineer") who was
previously the director of CoreWare at [LSI Logic](/wiki/LSI_Logic "LSI
Logic") and a [microprocessor](/wiki/Microprocessor "Microprocessor") designer
at [AMD](/wiki/AMD "AMD"); [Chris Malachowsky](/wiki/Chris_Malachowsky "Chris
Malachowsky"), an engineer who worked at [Sun
Microsystems](/wiki/Sun_Microsystems "Sun Microsystems"); and [Curtis
Priem](/wiki/Curtis_Priem "Curtis Priem"), who was previously a senior staff
engineer and [graphics chip](/wiki/Graphics_chip "Graphics chip") designer at
[IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") and Sun Microsystems.[26][27] The three men founded the
company in a meeting at a [Denny's](/wiki/Denny%27s "Denny's") roadside diner
in [East San Jose](/wiki/East_San_Jose "East San Jose") (just off [Interstate
680](/wiki/Interstate_680_\(California\) "Interstate 680 \(California\)") at
the Berryessa Road interchange).[28][29]

In 1993, the three co-founders envisioned that the ideal trajectory for the
forthcoming wave of computing would be in the realm of accelerated computing,
specifically in graphics-based processing. This path was chosen due to its
unique ability to tackle challenges that eluded general-purpose computing
methods.[30] They also observed that video games were simultaneously one of
the most computationally challenging problems and would have incredibly high
sales volume; the two conditions do not happen very often.[30] Video games
became the company's flywheel to reach large markets and fund huge R&D to
solve massive computational problems.[30] With $40,000 in the bank, the
company was born.[30] The company subsequently received $20 million of venture
capital funding from [Sequoia Capital](/wiki/Sequoia_Capital "Sequoia
Capital") and others.[31]

Nvidia initially had no name and the co-founders named all their files NV, as
in "next version".[30] The need to incorporate the company prompted the co-
founders to review all words with those two letters, leading them to
"[invidia](/wiki/Invidia "Invidia")", the Latin word for "envy".[30] The
company's original headquarters office was in [Sunnyvale,
California](/wiki/Sunnyvale,_California "Sunnyvale, California").

### First graphics
accelerator[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: First graphics accelerator")]

Nvidia's first graphics accelerator product, the [NV1](/wiki/NV1 "NV1"), was
optimized for processing quadratic [primitives](/wiki/Geometric_primitive
"Geometric primitive") instead of the triangle primitives preferred by its
competitors.[29] Then [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") introduced the
[DirectX](/wiki/DirectX "DirectX") platform, refused to support any other
graphics software,[32] and also announced that its graphics software
([Direct3D](/wiki/Direct3D "Direct3D")) would support only triangles.[29] In
1996, Huang laid off more than half of Nvidia's employees (then around 100)
and focused the company's remaining resources on developing a graphics
accelerator product optimized for processing triangle primitives: the [RIVA
128](/wiki/RIVA_128 "RIVA 128").[29][32] By the time the RIVA 128 was released
in August 1997, Nvidia only had enough money left for about one month of
payroll.[29] The sense of desperation around Nvidia during this difficult era
of its early history gave rise to "the unofficial company motto": "Our company
is thirty days from going out of business".[29] Nvidia sold about a million
RIVA 128s in about four months[29] and used the revenue to develop its next
generation of products.[32] In 1998, the release of the [RIVA
TNT](/wiki/RIVA_TNT "RIVA TNT") solidified Nvidia's reputation for developing
capable graphics adapters.

### Public company[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Public company")]

Nvidia went public on January 22, 1999.[33][34][35]

In late 1999, Nvidia released the [GeForce 256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce
256") (NV10), its first product expressly marketed as a GPU, which was most
notable for introducing onboard [transformation and
lighting](/wiki/Transform,_clipping,_and_lighting "Transform, clipping, and
lighting") (T&L) to consumer-level 3D hardware. Running at 120 MHz and
featuring four-pixel pipelines, it implemented advanced video acceleration,
motion compensation, and hardware sub-picture alpha blending. The GeForce
outperformed existing products by a wide margin.

Due to the success of its products, Nvidia won the contract to develop the
graphics hardware for [Microsoft's](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")
[Xbox](/wiki/Xbox_\(console\) "Xbox \(console\)") game console, which earned
Nvidia a $200 million advance. However, the project took many of its best
engineers away from other projects. In the short term this did not matter, and
the [GeForce2 GTS](/wiki/GeForce_2_Series "GeForce 2 Series") shipped in the
summer of 2000. In December 2000, Nvidia reached an agreement to acquire the
intellectual assets of its one-time rival [3dfx](/wiki/3dfx_Interactive "3dfx
Interactive"), a pioneer in consumer 3D graphics technology leading the field
from the mid-1990s until 2000.[36][37] The acquisition process was finalized
in April 2002.[38]

In July 2002, Nvidia acquired Exluna for an undisclosed sum. Exluna made
software-rendering tools and the personnel were merged into the Cg
project.

However, the project took many of its best
engineers away from other projects. In the short term this did not matter, and
the [GeForce2 GTS](/wiki/GeForce_2_Series "GeForce 2 Series") shipped in the
summer of 2000. In December 2000, Nvidia reached an agreement to acquire the
intellectual assets of its one-time rival [3dfx](/wiki/3dfx_Interactive "3dfx
Interactive"), a pioneer in consumer 3D graphics technology leading the field
from the mid-1990s until 2000.[36][37] The acquisition process was finalized
in April 2002.[38]

In July 2002, Nvidia acquired Exluna for an undisclosed sum. Exluna made
software-rendering tools and the personnel were merged into the Cg
project.[39] In August 2003, Nvidia acquired MediaQ for approximately US$70
million.[40] On April 22, 2004, Nvidia acquired iReady, also a provider of
high-performance TCP/IP and iSCSI offload solutions.[
_[buzzword](/wiki/Wikipedia:Use_plain_English#Buzzwords "Wikipedia:Use plain
English")_ ][41] In December 2004, it was announced that Nvidia would assist
[Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony") with the design of the graphics processor
([RSX](/wiki/RSX_%27Reality_Synthesizer%27 "RSX 'Reality Synthesizer'")) in
the [PlayStation 3](/wiki/PlayStation_3 "PlayStation 3") game console. On
December 14, 2005, Nvidia acquired [ULI
Electronics](/wiki/Acer_Laboratories_Incorporated "Acer Laboratories
Incorporated"), which at the time supplied third-party
[southbridge](/wiki/Southbridge_\(computing\) "Southbridge \(computing\)")
parts for [chipsets](/wiki/Chipset "Chipset") to [ATI](/wiki/ATI_Technologies
"ATI Technologies"), Nvidia's competitor.[42] In March 2006, Nvidia acquired
[Hybrid Graphics](/wiki/Hybrid_Graphics "Hybrid Graphics").[43] In December
2006, Nvidia, along with its main rival in the graphics industry AMD (which
had acquired ATI), received subpoenas from the [U.S. Department of
Justice](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department
of Justice") regarding possible [antitrust](/wiki/United_States_antitrust_law
"United States antitrust law") violations in the graphics card industry.[44]

### 2007 - 2014[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: 2007 - 2014")]

_[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ named Nvidia its _Company of the Year_ for
2007, citing the accomplishments it made during the said period as well as
during the previous five years.[45] On January 5, 2007, Nvidia announced that
it had completed the acquisition of [PortalPlayer,
Inc.](/wiki/PortalPlayer,_Inc. "PortalPlayer, Inc.")[46] In February 2008,
Nvidia acquired [Ageia](/wiki/Ageia "Ageia"), developer of [PhysX](/wiki/PhysX
"PhysX"), a [physics engine](/wiki/Physics_engine "Physics engine") and
[physics processing unit](/wiki/Physics_processing_unit "Physics processing
unit"). Nvidia announced that it planned to integrate the PhysX technology
into its future [GPU](/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit "Graphics processing
unit") products.[47][48]

In July 2008, Nvidia took a write-down of approximately $200 million on its
first-quarter revenue, after reporting that certain mobile chipsets and GPUs
produced by the company had "abnormal failure rates" due to manufacturing
defects. Nvidia, however, did not reveal the affected products. In September
2008, Nvidia became the subject of a class action lawsuit over the defects,
claiming that the faulty GPUs had been incorporated into certain laptop models
manufactured by [Apple Inc.](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc."), [Dell](/wiki/Dell
"Dell"), and [HP](/wiki/Hewlett-Packard "Hewlett-Packard"). In September 2010,
Nvidia reached a settlement, in which it would reimburse owners of the
affected laptops for repairs or, in some cases, replacement.

[47][48]

In July 2008, Nvidia took a write-down of approximately $200 million on its
first-quarter revenue, after reporting that certain mobile chipsets and GPUs
produced by the company had "abnormal failure rates" due to manufacturing
defects. Nvidia, however, did not reveal the affected products. In September
2008, Nvidia became the subject of a class action lawsuit over the defects,
claiming that the faulty GPUs had been incorporated into certain laptop models
manufactured by [Apple Inc.](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc."), [Dell](/wiki/Dell
"Dell"), and [HP](/wiki/Hewlett-Packard "Hewlett-Packard"). In September 2010,
Nvidia reached a settlement, in which it would reimburse owners of the
affected laptops for repairs or, in some cases, replacement.[49][50] On
January 10, 2011, Nvidia signed a six-year, $1.5 billion cross-licensing
agreement with Intel, ending all litigation between the two companies.[51]

In November 2011, after initially unveiling it at [Mobile World
Congress](/wiki/Mobile_World_Congress "Mobile World Congress"), Nvidia
released its [Tegra 3](/wiki/Tegra_3 "Tegra 3")
[ARM](/wiki/ARM_architecture_family "ARM architecture family") [system on a
chip](/wiki/System-on-chip "System-on-chip") for mobile devices. Nvidia
claimed that the chip featured the first-ever quad-core mobile CPU.[52][53] In
May 2011, it was announced that Nvidia had agreed to acquire
[Icera](/wiki/Icera "Icera"), a baseband chip making company in the UK, for
$367 million.[54] In January 2013, Nvidia unveiled the [Tegra 4](/wiki/Tegra_4
"Tegra 4"), as well as the [Nvidia Shield](/wiki/Shield_Portable "Shield
Portable"), an [Android](/wiki/Android_\(operating_system\) "Android
\(operating system\)")-based [handheld game
console](/wiki/Handheld_game_console "Handheld game console") powered by the
new system on a chip.[55] On July 29, 2013, Nvidia announced that they
acquired [PGI](/wiki/The_Portland_Group "The Portland Group") from
STMicroelectronics.[56]

In February 2013, Nvidia announced its plans to build a new headquarters in
the form of two giant triangle-shaped buildings on the other side of San Tomas
Expressway (to the west of its existing headquarters complex). The company
selected triangles as its design theme. As Huang explained in a blog post, the
triangle is "the fundamental building block of computer graphics".[57]

In 2014, Nvidia ported the [Valve](/wiki/Valve_Corporation "Valve
Corporation") games _[Portal](/wiki/Portal_\(video_game\) "Portal \(video
game\)")_ and _[Half Life 2](/wiki/Half-Life_2 "Half-Life 2")_ to its Nvidia
Shield tablet as Lightspeed Studio.[58][59] Since 2014, Nvidia has diversified
its business focusing on three markets: gaming, automotive electronics, and
mobile devices.[60]

### 2016 - 2018[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: 2016 - 2018")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/TitanXP.jpg/220px-
TitanXP.jpg)](/wiki/File:TitanXP.jpg)Nvidia Titan X, part of the [GeForce 10
series](/wiki/GeForce_10_series "GeForce 10 series")

On May 6, 2016, Nvidia unveiled the first GPUs of the [GeForce 10
series](/wiki/GeForce_10_series "GeForce 10 series"), the GTX 1080 and 1070,
based on the company's new [Pascal](/wiki/Pascal_microarchitecture "Pascal
microarchitecture") microarchitecture. Nvidia claimed that both models
outperformed its [Maxwell](/wiki/Maxwell_\(microarchitecture\) "Maxwell
\(microarchitecture\)")-based Titan X model; the models incorporate GDDR5X and
[GDDR5](/wiki/GDDR5 "GDDR5") memory respectively, and use a 16 nm
manufacturing process.

Nvidia claimed that both models
outperformed its [Maxwell](/wiki/Maxwell_\(microarchitecture\) "Maxwell
\(microarchitecture\)")-based Titan X model; the models incorporate GDDR5X and
[GDDR5](/wiki/GDDR5 "GDDR5") memory respectively, and use a 16 nm
manufacturing process. The architecture also supports a new hardware feature
known as simultaneous multi-projection (SMP), which is designed to improve the
quality of multi-monitor and [virtual reality](/wiki/Virtual_reality "Virtual
reality") rendering.[61][62][63] Laptops that include these GPUs and are
sufficiently thin – as of late 2017, under 0.8 inches (20 mm) – have been
designated as meeting Nvidia's "Max-Q" design standard.[64]

In July 2016, Nvidia agreed to a settlement for a [false
advertising](/wiki/False_advertising "False advertising") lawsuit regarding
its [GTX 970](/wiki/GTX_970 "GTX 970") model, as the models were unable to use
all of their advertised 4 GB of RAM due to limitations brought by the design
of its hardware.[65] In May 2017, Nvidia announced a partnership with
[Toyota](/wiki/Toyota "Toyota") which will use Nvidia's [Drive PX-
series](/wiki/Drive_PX-series "Drive PX-series") artificial intelligence
platform for its autonomous vehicles.[66] In July 2017, Nvidia and Chinese
search giant [Baidu](/wiki/Baidu "Baidu") announced a far-reaching AI
partnership that includes cloud computing, autonomous driving, consumer
devices, and Baidu's open-source AI framework PaddlePaddle. Baidu unveiled
that Nvidia's Drive PX 2 AI will be the foundation of its autonomous-vehicle
platform.[67]

Nvidia officially released the Titan V on December 7, 2017.[68][69]

Nvidia officially released the Nvidia Quadro GV100 on March 27, 2018.[70]
Nvidia officially released the RTX 2080 GPUs on September 27, 2018. In 2018,
[Google](/wiki/Google "Google") announced that Nvidia's Tesla P4 graphic cards
would be integrated into Google Cloud service's artificial intelligence.[71]

In May 2018, on the Nvidia user forum, a thread was started[72] asking the
company to update users when they would release web drivers for its cards
installed on legacy [Mac Pro](/wiki/Mac_Pro "Mac Pro") machines up to
[mid-2012 5,1](/wiki/Mac_Pro#1st_generation_\(tower\) "Mac Pro") running the
[macOS Mojave](/wiki/MacOS_Mojave "MacOS Mojave") operating system 10.14. [Web
drivers](/wiki/Device_driver "Device driver") are required to enable graphics
acceleration and multiple [display monitor](/wiki/Computer_monitor "Computer
monitor") capabilities of the GPU. On its Mojave update info website, Apple
stated that macOS Mojave would run on legacy machines with '[Metal
compatible](/wiki/Metal_\(API\) "Metal \(API\)")' graphics cards[73] and
listed Metal compatible GPUs, including some manufactured by Nvidia.[74]
However, this list did not include Metal compatible cards that currently work
in [macOS High Sierra](/wiki/MacOS_High_Sierra "MacOS High Sierra") using
Nvidia-developed web drivers. In September, Nvidia responded, "Apple fully
controls drivers for macOS. But if Apple allows, our engineers are ready and
eager to help Apple deliver great drivers for macOS 10.14 (Mojave)."[75] In
October, Nvidia followed this up with another public announcement, "Apple
fully controls drivers for macOS. Unfortunately, Nvidia currently cannot
release a driver unless it is approved by Apple,"[76] suggesting a possible
rift between the two companies.[77] By January 2019, with still no sign of the
enabling web drivers, [Apple Insider](/wiki/Apple_community#AppleInsider
"Apple community") weighed into the controversy with a claim that Apple
management "doesn't want Nvidia support in macOS".[78] The following month,
Apple Insider followed this up with another claim that Nvidia support was
abandoned because of "relational issues in the past",[79] and that Apple was
developing its own GPU technology.
