Apple Insider followed this up with another claim that Nvidia support was
abandoned because of "relational issues in the past",[79] and that Apple was
developing its own GPU technology.[80] Without Apple-approved Nvidia web
drivers, Apple users are faced with replacing their Nvidia cards with a
competing supported brand, such as [AMD Radeon](/wiki/AMD_Radeon "AMD Radeon")
from the list recommended by Apple.[81]

### 2019, acquisition of Mellanox
Technologies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: 2019, acquisition of Mellanox Technologies")]

See also: [Mellanox Technologies](/wiki/Mellanox_Technologies "Mellanox
Technologies")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Nvidia_Yokneam_Office.jpg/240px-
Nvidia_Yokneam_Office.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nvidia_Yokneam_Office.jpg)Nvidia
Yokneam office (former [Mellanox Technologies](/wiki/Mellanox_Technologies
"Mellanox Technologies")) in [Yokneam Illit](/wiki/Yokneam_Illit "Yokneam
Illit"), [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel"), March 2023

On March 11, 2019, Nvidia announced a deal to buy [Mellanox
Technologies](/wiki/Mellanox_Technologies "Mellanox Technologies") for $6.9
billion[82] to substantially expand its footprint in the high-performance
computing market. In May 2019, Nvidia announced new RTX Studio laptops. The
creators say that the new laptop is going to be seven times faster than a top-
end MacBook Pro with a Core i9 and AMD's Radeon Pro Vega 20 graphics in apps
like [Maya](/wiki/Autodesk_Maya "Autodesk Maya") and RedCine-X Pro.[83] In
August 2019, Nvidia announced _[Minecraft RTX](/wiki/Minecraft_RTX "Minecraft
RTX")_ , an official Nvidia-developed patch for the game
_[Minecraft](/wiki/Minecraft "Minecraft")_ adding real-time DXR ray tracing
exclusively to the Windows 10 version of the game. The whole game is, in
Nvidia's words, "refit" with [path tracing](/wiki/Path_tracing "Path
tracing"), which dramatically affects the way light, reflections, and shadows
work inside the engine.[84]

### 2020 - 2023[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 2020 - 2023")]

In May 2020, Nvidia's top scientists developed an [open-
source](/wiki/Open_source "Open source") [ventilator](/wiki/Ventilator
"Ventilator") to address the shortage resulting from the global [coronavirus
pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic").[85] On May 14, 2020,
Nvidia officially announced their Ampere GPU microarchitecture and the Nvidia
A100 GPU accelerator.[86][87] In July 2020, it was reported that Nvidia was in
talks with [SoftBank](/wiki/SoftBank_Group "SoftBank Group") to buy
[Arm](/wiki/Arm_\(company\) "Arm \(company\)"), a UK-based chip designer, for
$32 billion.[88]

On September 1, 2020, Nvidia officially announced the [GeForce 30
series](/wiki/GeForce_30_series "GeForce 30 series") based on the company's
new [Ampere](/wiki/Ampere_\(microarchitecture\) "Ampere
\(microarchitecture\)") microarchitecture.

[85] On May 14, 2020,
Nvidia officially announced their Ampere GPU microarchitecture and the Nvidia
A100 GPU accelerator.[86][87] In July 2020, it was reported that Nvidia was in
talks with [SoftBank](/wiki/SoftBank_Group "SoftBank Group") to buy
[Arm](/wiki/Arm_\(company\) "Arm \(company\)"), a UK-based chip designer, for
$32 billion.[88]

On September 1, 2020, Nvidia officially announced the [GeForce 30
series](/wiki/GeForce_30_series "GeForce 30 series") based on the company's
new [Ampere](/wiki/Ampere_\(microarchitecture\) "Ampere
\(microarchitecture\)") microarchitecture.[89][90]

On September 13, 2020, it was announced that Nvidia would buy Arm from
SoftBank Group for $40 billion, subject to the usual scrutiny, with the latter
retaining a 10% share of Nvidia.[91][92][93][94]

In October 2020, Nvidia announced its plan to build the most powerful computer
in [Cambridge, England](/wiki/Cambridge "Cambridge"). The computer, called
Cambridge-1, launched in July 2021 with a $100 million investment and will
employ AI to support [healthcare research](/wiki/Medical_open_network_for_AI
"Medical open network for AI").[95][96] According to Jensen Huang, "The
Cambridge-1 supercomputer will serve as a hub of innovation for the UK, and
further the groundbreaking work being done by the nation's researchers in
critical healthcare and drug discovery."[97]

Also in October 2020, along with the release of the [Nvidia
RTX](/wiki/Nvidia_RTX "Nvidia RTX") A6000, Nvidia announced it is retiring its
workstation GPU brand Quadro, shifting its product name to Nvidia RTX for
future products and the manufacturing to be [Nvidia Ampere
architecture](/wiki/Ampere_\(microarchitecture\) "Ampere
\(microarchitecture\)")-based.[7]

In August 2021, the proposed takeover of Arm was stalled after the UK's
[Competition and Markets Authority](/wiki/Competition_and_Markets_Authority
"Competition and Markets Authority") raised "significant competition
concerns".[98] In October 2021, the [European
Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") opened a
competition investigation into the takeover. The Commission stated that
Nvidia's acquisition could restrict competitors' access to Arm's products and
provide Nvidia with too much internal information on its competitors due to
their deals with Arm. SoftBank (the parent company of Arm) and Nvidia
announced in early February 2022 that they "had agreed not to move forward
with the transaction 'because of significant regulatory challenges'".[99] The
investigation is set to end on March 15, 2022.[100][101] That same month,
Nvidia was reportedly compromised by a cyberattack.[102]

In March 2022, Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang mentioned that they are open to
having Intel manufacture their chips in the future.[103] This was the first
time the company mentioned that they would work together with Intel's upcoming
foundry services.

In April 2022, it was reported that Nvidia planned to open a new research
center in [Yerevan, Armenia](/wiki/Yerevan,_Armenia "Yerevan, Armenia").[104]

In May 2022, Nvidia opened Voyager, the second of the two giant triangle-
shaped buildings at its new headquarters complex to the west of the old one.
Unlike its smaller and older sibling Endeavor, the triangle theming is used
more "sparingly" in Voyager.[105][106]

In September 2022, Nvidia announced its next-generation automotive-grade chip,
[Drive Thor](/wiki/Nvidia_Drive#DRIVE_Thor "Nvidia Drive").[107][108]

Following [U.S. Department of Commerce](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Commerce
"U.S. Department of Commerce") regulations which placed an [embargo on exports
to
China](/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war#Biden_administration_restrictions
"China–United States trade war") of advanced microchips, which went into
effect in October 2022, Nvidia saw its data center chip added to the export
control list. The next month, the company unveiled a new advanced chip in
China, called the A800 GPU, that met the export control rules.

In September 2023, [Getty Images](/wiki/Getty_Images "Getty Images") announced
that it was partnering with Nvidia to launch Generative AI by Getty Images, a
new tool that lets people create images using Getty's library of licensed
photos. Getty will use Nvidia's Edify model, which is available on Nvidia's
generative AI model library Picasso.[110]

### 2023 - present, passing the $1 trillion
mark[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section:
2023 - present, passing the $1 trillion mark")]

On September 26, 2023, Denny's CEO [Kelli Valade](/wiki/Kelli_Valade "Kelli
Valade") joined Huang in East San Jose to celebrate the founding of Nvidia at
the Denny's on Berryessa Road, where a plaque was installed to mark the
relevant corner booth as the birthplace of a $1 trillion company.[29][111] By
then Nvidia's [H100](/wiki/Hopper_\(microarchitecture\) "Hopper
\(microarchitecture\)") GPUs were in such demand that even other [tech
giants](/wiki/Tech_giant "Tech giant") were beholden to how Nvidia allocated
supply. [Larry Ellison](/wiki/Larry_Ellison "Larry Ellison") of [Oracle
Corporation](/wiki/Oracle_Corporation "Oracle Corporation") said that month
that during a dinner with Huang, he and [Elon Musk](/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon
Musk") of [Tesla, Inc.](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.") and
[xAI](/wiki/XAI_\(company\) "XAI \(company\)") "were begging" for H100s, "I
guess is the best way to describe it. An hour of sushi and begging".[112]

In October 2023, it was reported that Nvidia had quietly begun designing [ARM-
based](/wiki/ARM_architecture_family "ARM architecture family") central
processing units (CPUs) for Microsoft's [Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows
"Microsoft Windows") operating system with a target to start selling them in
2025.[113]

In February 2024, it was reported that Nvidia was the "hot employer" in
Silicon Valley, because it was offering interesting work and good pay at a
time when other tech employers were downsizing. Half of Nvidia employees
earned over $228,000 in 2023.[114]

## Fabless
manufacturing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Fabless manufacturing")]

Nvidia uses external suppliers for all phases of manufacturing, including
wafer fabrication, assembly, testing, and packaging. Nvidia thus avoids most
of the investment and production costs and risks associated with chip
manufacturing, although it does sometimes directly procure some raw materials
used in production of its products (e.g. memory and substrates). Nvidia
focuses its own resources on product design, quality assurance, marketing, and
customer support.[115][116]

## Finances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Finances")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/NVIDIA_Stock_Price.webp/235px-
NVIDIA_Stock_Price.webp.png)](/wiki/File:NVIDIA_Stock_Price.webp)Nvidia stock
price (1999–2023)

For the [fiscal year](/wiki/Fiscal_year "Fiscal year") 2020, Nvidia reported
earnings of US$2.796 billion, with an annual revenue of US$10.918 billion, a
decline of 6.8% over the previous fiscal cycle. Nvidia's shares traded at over
$531 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$328.7
billion in January 2021.[117]

For the Q2 of 2020, Nvidia reported sales of $3.87 billion, which was a 50%
rise from the same period in 2019. The surge in sales and people's higher
demand for computer technology. According to the financial chief of the
company, Colette Kress, the effects of the pandemic will "likely reflect this
evolution in enterprise workforce trends with a greater focus on technologies,
such as Nvidia laptops and virtual workstations, that enable remote work and
virtual collaboration."[118] In May 2023, Nvidia [crossed $1
trillion](/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization "List of
public corporations by market capitalization") in [market
valuation](/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization") during trading
hours,[119] and grew to $1.2 trillion by the following November.[120] For its
strength, size and market capitalization, Nvidia has been selected to be one
of Bloomberg's "Magnificent Seven", the seven biggest companies on the stock
market in these regards.

## GPU Technology
Conference[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: GPU Technology Conference")]

Main article: [Nvidia GTC](/wiki/Nvidia_GTC "Nvidia GTC")

Nvidia's GPU Technology Conference (GTC) is a series of technical conferences
held around the world.[121] It originated in 2009 in [San Jose,
California](/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California"), with an
initial focus on the potential for solving computing challenges through
GPUs.[122] In recent years, the conference focus has shifted to various
applications of artificial intelligence and [deep
learning](/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning"); including [self-driving
cars](/wiki/Autonomous_car "Autonomous car"), healthcare, [high-performance
computing](/wiki/High_Performance_Computing "High Performance Computing"), and
Nvidia Deep Learning Institute (DLI) training.[123] GTC 2018 attracted over
8400 attendees.[121] GTC 2020 was converted to a digital event and drew
roughly 59,000 registrants.[124]

## Product families[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Product families")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/NVIDIA_Shield_Tablet_with_Wireless_Controller_%2816131034479%29.jpg/220px-
NVIDIA_Shield_Tablet_with_Wireless_Controller_%2816131034479%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:NVIDIA_Shield_Tablet_with_Wireless_Controller_\(16131034479\).jpg)A
[Shield Tablet](/wiki/Shield_Tablet "Shield Tablet") with its accompanying
input pen (left) and [gamepad](/wiki/Gamepad "Gamepad")

Nvidia's product families include graphics processing units, wireless
communication devices, and automotive hardware and software, such as:

  * [GeForce](/wiki/GeForce "GeForce"), consumer-oriented graphics processing products
  * [Nvidia RTX](/wiki/Nvidia_RTX "Nvidia RTX"), professional visual computing graphics processing products (replacing GTX and [Quadro](/wiki/Quadro "Quadro"))
  * [NVS](/wiki/Nvidia_Quadro#For_business_NVS "Nvidia Quadro"), multi-display business graphics solution[ _[buzzword](/wiki/Wikipedia:Use_plain_English#Buzzwords "Wikipedia:Use plain English")_ ]
  * [Tegra](/wiki/Tegra "Tegra"), a [system on a chip](/wiki/System_on_a_chip "System on a chip") series for mobile devices
  * [Tesla](/wiki/Nvidia_Tesla "Nvidia Tesla"), dedicated general-purpose GPU for high-end image generation applications in professional and scientific fields
  * [nForce](/wiki/NForce "NForce"), a motherboard chipset created by Nvidia for Intel (Celeron, Pentium and Core 2) and AMD (Athlon and Duron) microprocessors
  * Nvidia GRID, a set of hardware and services by Nvidia for graphics virtualization
  * Nvidia Shield, a range of gaming hardware including the [Shield Portable](/wiki/Shield_Portable "Shield Portable"), [Shield Tablet](/wiki/Shield_Tablet "Shield Tablet") and, most recently, the [Shield Android TV](/wiki/Shield_Android_TV "Shield Android TV")
  * Nvidia Drive, a range of hardware and software products for designers and manufacturers of autonomous vehicles. The [Drive PX-series](/wiki/Drive_PX-series "Drive PX-series") is a high-performance computer platform aimed at autonomous driving through deep learning,[125] while Driveworks is an operating system for [driverless cars](/wiki/Self-driving_car "Self-driving car").[126]
  * [Nvidia BlueField](/wiki/Nvidia_BlueField "Nvidia BlueField"), a range of [data processing units](/wiki/Data_processing_unit "Data processing unit"), initially inherited from their acquisition of [Mellanox Technologies](/wiki/Mellanox_Technologies "Mellanox Technologies")[127][128]
  * Nvidia Datacenter/Server class CPU, codenamed Nvidia Grace, released in 2023[129][130]

Until September 23, 2013, Nvidia had not published any documentation for its
advanced hardware,[131] meaning that programmers could not write [free and
open-source](/wiki/Free_and_open-source "Free and open-source") [device
driver](/wiki/Device_driver "Device driver") for its products without
resorting to ([clean room](/wiki/Clean_room_design "Clean room design"))
[reverse engineering](/wiki/Reverse_engineering "Reverse engineering").

Instead, Nvidia provides its own [binary](/wiki/Binary_file "Binary file")
GeForce graphics drivers for [X.Org](/wiki/X.Org_Server "X.Org Server") and an
open-source library that interfaces with the [Linux](/wiki/Linux_kernel "Linux
kernel"), [FreeBSD](/wiki/FreeBSD "FreeBSD") or
[Solaris](/wiki/Solaris_\(operating_system\) "Solaris \(operating system\)")
kernels and the [proprietary](/wiki/Proprietary_software "Proprietary
software") graphics software. Nvidia also provided but stopped supporting an
obfuscated open-source driver that only supports two-dimensional hardware
acceleration and ships with the X.Org distribution.[132]

The proprietary nature of Nvidia's drivers has generated dissatisfaction
within [free-software communities](/wiki/Free_software_community "Free
software community"). In a 2012 talk, [Linus Torvalds](/wiki/Linus_Torvalds
"Linus Torvalds"), in criticism of Nvidia's approach towards Linux, raised
[the finger](/wiki/The_finger "The finger") and stated "Nvidia,
[fuck](/wiki/Fuck "Fuck") you."[133][134] Some Linux and BSD users insist on
using only open-source drivers and regard Nvidia's insistence on providing
nothing more than a binary-only driver as inadequate, given that competing
manufacturers such as [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel") offer support and
documentation for [open-source](/wiki/Open-source_model "Open-source model")
developers and that others (like [AMD](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced
Micro Devices")) release partial documentation and provide some active
development.[135][136]

Because of the closed nature of the drivers, Nvidia video cards cannot deliver
adequate features on some platforms and architectures, given that the company
only provides x86/x64 and ARMv7-A driver builds.[137] As a result, support for
3D graphics acceleration in Linux on [PowerPC](/wiki/PowerPC "PowerPC") does
not exist, nor does support for Linux on the [hypervisor](/wiki/Hypervisor
"Hypervisor")-restricted [PlayStation 3](/wiki/PlayStation_3 "PlayStation 3")
console.[ _[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ]

Some users claim that Nvidia's Linux drivers impose artificial restrictions,
like limiting the number of monitors that can be used at the same time, but
the company has not commented on these accusations.[138]

In 2014, with Maxwell GPUs, Nvidia started to require firmware by them to
unlock all features of its graphics cards.[139][140][141]

On 12 May 2022, Nvidia announced that they are opensourcing their GPU kernel
modules.[142][143][144] Support for Nvidia's firmware was implemented in
nouveau in 2023, which allows proper power management and GPU reclocking for
Turing and newer graphics cards.

[ _[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ]

Some users claim that Nvidia's Linux drivers impose artificial restrictions,
like limiting the number of monitors that can be used at the same time, but
the company has not commented on these accusations.[138]

In 2014, with Maxwell GPUs, Nvidia started to require firmware by them to

On 12 May 2022, Nvidia announced that they are opensourcing their GPU kernel
modules.[142][143][144] Support for Nvidia's firmware was implemented in
nouveau in 2023, which allows proper power management and GPU reclocking for
Turing and newer graphics cards.[145][146]

## Deep learning[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Deep learning")]

Nvidia GPUs are used in [deep learning](/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning"),
and accelerated analytics due to Nvidia's [CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") API which
allows programmers to utilize the higher number of cores present in GPUs to
[parallelize](/wiki/Parallel_computing "Parallel computing") [BLAS](/wiki/BLAS
"BLAS") operations which are extensively used in [machine
learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning") algorithms.[10] They were
included in many Tesla, Inc. vehicles before Musk announced at Tesla Autonomy
Day in 2019 that the company developed its own SoC and full self-driving
computer now and would stop using Nvidia hardware for their
vehicles.[147][148] These GPUs are used by researchers, laboratories, tech
companies and enterprise companies.[149] In 2009, Nvidia was involved in what
was called the "big bang" of deep learning, "as deep-learning neural networks
were combined with Nvidia graphics processing units (GPUs)".[150] That year,
the [Google Brain](/wiki/Google_Brain "Google Brain") used Nvidia GPUs to
create Deep Neural Networks capable of machine learning, where [Andrew
Ng](/wiki/Andrew_Ng "Andrew Ng") determined that GPUs could increase the speed
of deep-learning systems by about 100 times.[151]

### DGX[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section:
DGX")]

Main article: [Nvidia DGX](/wiki/Nvidia_DGX "Nvidia DGX")

DGX is a line of [supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputers "Supercomputers") by
Nvidia.

In April 2016, Nvidia produced the [DGX-1](/wiki/DGX-1 "DGX-1") based on an 8
GPU cluster, to improve the ability of users to use deep learning by combining
GPUs with integrated deep learning software.[152] Nvidia gifted its first
DGX-1 to [OpenAI](/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI") in August 2016 to help it train
larger and more complex AI models with the capability of reducing processing
time from six days to two hours.[153][154] It also developed Nvidia Tesla K80
and P100 GPU-based virtual machines, which are available through [Google
Cloud](/wiki/Google_Cloud_Platform "Google Cloud Platform"), which Google
installed in November 2016.[155] [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")
added GPU servers in a preview offering of its N series based on Nvidia's
Tesla K80s, each containing 4992 processing cores. Later that year, AWS's P2
instance was produced using up to 16 Nvidia Tesla K80 GPUs. That month Nvidia
also partnered with IBM to create a software kit that boosts the AI
capabilities of [Watson](/wiki/Watson_\(computer\) "Watson
\(computer\)"),[156] called IBM PowerAI.[157][158] Nvidia also offers its own
Nvidia Deep Learning software development kit.[159] In 2017, the GPUs were
also brought online at the [Riken](/wiki/Riken "Riken") Center for Advanced
Intelligence Project for [Fujitsu](/wiki/Fujitsu "Fujitsu").[160] The
company's deep learning technology led to a boost in its 2017 earnings.[161]

In May 2018, researchers at the artificial intelligence department of Nvidia
realized the possibility that a robot can learn to perform a job simply by
observing the person doing the same job. They have created a system that,
after a short revision and testing, can already be used to control the
universal robots of the next generation.

[157][158] Nvidia also offers its own
Nvidia Deep Learning software development kit.[159] In 2017, the GPUs were
also brought online at the [Riken](/wiki/Riken "Riken") Center for Advanced
Intelligence Project for [Fujitsu](/wiki/Fujitsu "Fujitsu").[160] The
company's deep learning technology led to a boost in its 2017 earnings.[161]

In May 2018, researchers at the artificial intelligence department of Nvidia
realized the possibility that a robot can learn to perform a job simply by
observing the person doing the same job. They have created a system that,
after a short revision and testing, can already be used to control the
universal robots of the next generation. In addition to GPU manufacturing,
Nvidia provides parallel processing capabilities to researchers and scientists
that allow them to efficiently run high-performance applications.[162]

## Inception Program[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Inception Program")]

Nvidia's **Inception Program** was created to support startups making
exceptional advances in the fields of artificial intelligence and data
science. Award winners are announced at Nvidia's GTC Conference. In May 2017,
the program had 1,300 companies.[163] As of March 2018, there were 2,800
startups in the Inception Program.[164] As of August 2021, the program has
surpassed 8,500 members in 90 countries, with cumulative funding of US$60
billion.[165]

### GeForce Partner
Program[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section:
GeForce Partner Program")]

Main article: [GeForce Partner Program](/wiki/GeForce_Partner_Program "GeForce
Partner Program")

The Nvidia GeForce Partner Program was a [marketing](/wiki/Marketing
"Marketing") program designed to provide partnering companies with benefits
such as public relations support, [video game](/wiki/Video_game "Video game")
bundling, and marketing development funds.[166] The program proved to be
controversial, with complaints about it possibly being an [anti-
competitive](/wiki/Anti-competitive "Anti-competitive") practice.[167]

First announced in a blog post on March 1, 2018,[168] it was canceled on May
4, 2018.[169]

### Hardware Unboxed
controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Hardware Unboxed controversy")]

On December 10, 2020, Nvidia told popular [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube")
tech reviewer Steven Walton of Hardware Unboxed that it would no longer supply
him with GeForce Founders Edition graphics card review units.[170][171] In a
Twitter message, Hardware Unboxed said, "Nvidia have officially decided to ban
us from receiving GeForce Founders Edition GPU review samples. Their reasoning
is that we are focusing on rasterization instead of ray tracing. They have
said they will revisit this 'should your editorial direction change.'"[172]

In emails that were disclosed by Walton from Nvidia Senior PR Manager Bryan
Del Rizzo, Nvidia had said:

> ...your GPU reviews and recommendations have continued to focus singularly
> on rasterization performance, and you have largely discounted all of the
> other technologies we offer gamers. It is very clear from your community
> commentary that you do not see things the same way that we, gamers, and the
> rest of the industry do.[173]

TechSpot, partner site of Hardware Unboxed, said, "this and other related
incidents raise serious questions around journalistic independence and what
they are expecting of reviewers when they are sent products for an unbiased
opinion."[173]

A number of prominent technology reviewers came out strongly against Nvidia's
move.

is that we are focusing on rasterization instead of ray tracing. They have
said they will revisit this 'should your editorial direction change.'"[172]

In emails that were disclosed by Walton from Nvidia Senior PR Manager Bryan
Del Rizzo, Nvidia had said:

> ...your GPU reviews and recommendations have continued to focus singularly
> on rasterization performance, and you have largely discounted all of the
> other technologies we offer gamers. It is very clear from your community
> commentary that you do not see things the same way that we, gamers, and the
> rest of the industry do.[173]

TechSpot, partner site of Hardware Unboxed, said, "this and other related
incidents raise serious questions around journalistic independence and what
they are expecting of reviewers when they are sent products for an unbiased
opinion."[173]

A number of prominent technology reviewers came out strongly against Nvidia's
move.[174][175] [Linus Sebastian](/wiki/Linus_Sebastian "Linus Sebastian"), of
Linus Tech Tips, titled the episode of his popular weekly WAN Show, "NVIDIA
might ACTUALLY be EVIL..."[176] and was highly critical of the company's move
to dictate specific outcomes of technology reviews.[177] The popular review
site Gamers Nexus said it was, "Nvidia's latest decision to shoot both its
feet: They've now made it so that any reviewers covering RT will become
subject to scrutiny from untrusting viewers who will suspect subversion by the
company. Shortsighted self-own from NVIDIA."[178]

Two days later, Nvidia reversed their stance.[179][180] Hardware Unboxed sent
out a Twitter message, "I just received an email from Nvidia apologizing for
the previous email & they've now walked everything back."[181][174] On
December 14, Hardware Unboxed released a video explaining the controversy from
their viewpoint.[182] Via Twitter, they also shared a second apology sent by
Nvidia's Del Rizzo that said "to withhold samples because I didn't agree with
your commentary is simply inexcusable and crossed the line."[183][184]

### Improper disclosures about
cryptomining[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nvidia&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Improper disclosures about cryptomining")]

In 2018, Nvidia's chips became popular for [cryptomining](/wiki/Cryptomining
"Cryptomining"), the process of obtaining crypto rewards in exchange for
verifying transactions on distributed ledgers, the [U.S. Securities and
Exchange Commission](/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "U.S.
Securities and Exchange Commission") (SEC) said. However, the company failed
to disclose that it was a "significant element" of its revenue growth from
sales of chips designed for gaming, the SEC further added in a statement and
charging order. Those omissions misled investors and analysts who were
interested in understanding the impact of cryptomining on Nvidia's business,
the SEC emphasized. Nvidia, which did not admit or deny the findings, has
agreed to pay $5.5 million to settle civil charges, according to a statement
made by the SEC in May 2022.[185]

The **GeForce 40 series** is a family of [graphics processing
units](/wiki/Graphics_processing_units "Graphics processing units") developed
by [Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia"), succeeding the [GeForce 30
series](/wiki/GeForce_30_series "GeForce 30 series"). The series was announced
on September 20, 2022, at the [GPU Technology
Conference](/wiki/GPU_Technology_Conference "GPU Technology Conference") (GTC)
2022 event.

The series was announced
on September 20, 2022, at the [GPU Technology
Conference](/wiki/GPU_Technology_Conference "GPU Technology Conference") (GTC)
2022 event.

The RTX 4090 was released as the first model of the series on October 12,
2022,[1] and the 16GB RTX 4080 was released on November 16, 2022. An RTX 4080
12GB was announced in September 2022, but following some controversy in the
media, was "unlaunched" by Nvidia. On January 5, 2023, that model would be
released as the RTX 4070 Ti. The RTX 4070 was then released on April 13, 2023.
The RTX 4060 Ti was released on May 24, 2023, and the RTX 4060 on June 29,
2023. An RTX 4060 Ti 16GB followed on July 18, 2023. Further models of this
generation of desktop and mobile GPUs are to release later in 2023.[3][
_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_ ] On January 8, 2024, Nvidia
released the RTX 4070 SUPER, RTX 4070 Ti SUPER and RTX 4080 SUPER video cards
at higher specs and lower prices than their original counterparts.[4] In the
same vein the production of the RTX 4080 and RTX 4070 Ti have stopped due to
the SUPER series, but the 4070 will remain.[5]

The cards are based on Nvidia's [Ada
Lovelace](/wiki/Ada_Lovelace_\(microarchitecture\) "Ada Lovelace
\(microarchitecture\)") architecture and feature Nvidia's third-generation RT
cores for hardware-accelerated [ray tracing](/wiki/Real-time_ray_tracing
"Real-time ray tracing") ([RTX](/wiki/Nvidia_RTX "Nvidia RTX")), and fourth-
generation [deep-learning](/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning")-focused
[Tensor Cores](/wiki/Tensor_Cores "Tensor Cores").

## Details[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Details")]

Architectural highlights of the Ada Lovelace architecture include the
following:[6]

  * [CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") Compute Capability 8.9[7]
  * [TSMC](/wiki/TSMC "TSMC") 4N process (custom designed for Nvidia)[1] – not to be confused with N4
  * Fourth-generation Tensor Cores with FP8, FP16, bfloat16, TensorFloat-32 (TF32) and sparsity acceleration
  * Third-generation Ray Tracing Cores, along with concurrent ray tracing, shading and compute
  * Shader Execution Reordering – needs to be enabled by the developer[8]
  * Dual [NVENC](/wiki/NVENC "NVENC") with 8K 10-bit 60FPS [AV1](/wiki/AV1 "AV1") fixed function hardware encoding[9][10]
  * A new generation of Optical Flow Accelerator to aid [DLSS 3.0](/wiki/Deep_learning_super_sampling#DLSS_3.0 "Deep learning super sampling") intermediate AI-based frame generation[11]
  * No [NVLink](/wiki/NVLink "NVLink") support[12][13]
  * [DisplayPort 1.4a](/wiki/DisplayPort#1.4a "DisplayPort") and [HDMI 2.1](/wiki/HDMI#Version_2.1 "HDMI") display connections
  * Double-precision ([FP64](/wiki/Double-precision_floating-point_format "Double-precision floating-point format")) performance of the [Ada Lovelace](/wiki/Ada_Lovelace_\(microarchitecture\) "Ada Lovelace \(microarchitecture\)") chips are 1/64 of single-precision ([FP32](/wiki/Single-precision_floating-point_format "Single-precision floating-point format")) performance.

##
Controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Controversies")]

### RTX 4080
12GB[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: RTX 4080 12GB")]

When the 12GB variant of the RTX 4080 was announced, numerous publications,
prominent YouTubers, reviewers, and the community criticized Nvidia for
marketing it as an RTX 4080, given the equivalent performance of previous
xx80-class cards when compared with other cards of the same series, and the
large gap in specifications and performance compared to the 16GB
variant.[45][46][47][48] The criticism focussed on Nvidia's naming scheme -
two 4080 models were to be offered, an "RTX 4080 12GB" and an "RTX 4080 16GB"
- the obvious interpretation was that the only difference between the two
products would be a difference in VRAM capacity. However, unlike other
examples of Nvidia GPUs with differing memory configurations within the same
class which have typically been very close in processing performance, the RTX
4080 12GB uses a completely different processing unit and memory architecture:
the 4080 12GB would use the AD104 chip, which features 27% fewer CUDA cores
than the 16GB variant's AD103 chip. It would also have a reduced
[TDP](/wiki/Thermal_design_power "Thermal design power") (285W - the 16GB
variant was configured to draw up to 320W), and a cut-down 192-bit memory bus.
In prior generations (e.g. the [GeForce
10](/wiki/GeForce_10_series#GeForce_10_\(10xx\)_series_for_desktops "GeForce
10 series"),
[20](/wiki/GeForce_20_series#GeForce_20_\(20xx\)_series_for_desktops "GeForce
20 series"), [30](/wiki/GeForce_30_series#Desktop "GeForce 30 series")
series), a 192-bit bus width had been reserved for xx60-class cards and
below.[45] These changes made the card up to 30% slower than the RTX 4080 16GB
in memory-agnostic performance, while being priced significantly higher than
previous xx70-class cards ($900 vs. $500 for the RTX 3070, approximately 80%
more expensive).

On October 14, 2022, Nvidia announced that due to the confusion caused by the
naming scheme, it would be "unlaunching"—i.e. postponing the launch of—the RTX
4080 12GB, with the RTX 4080 16GB's launch remaining unaffected.[49][50]

On January 3, 2023, Nvidia reintroduced the RTX 4080 12GB as the RTX 4070 Ti
during [CES 2023](/wiki/Consumer_Electronics_Show#2023 "Consumer Electronics
Show") and reduced its [list price](/wiki/List_price "List price") by $100.[3]
The 4070 Ti's production was stopped with the introduction of the 4070 Ti
SUPER.

On October 14, 2022, Nvidia announced that due to the confusion caused by the
naming scheme, it would be "unlaunching"—i.e. postponing the launch of—the RTX
4080 12GB, with the RTX 4080 16GB's launch remaining unaffected.[49][50]

On January 3, 2023, Nvidia reintroduced the RTX 4080 12GB as the RTX 4070 Ti
during [CES 2023](/wiki/Consumer_Electronics_Show#2023 "Consumer Electronics
Show") and reduced its [list price](/wiki/List_price "List price") by $100.[3]
The 4070 Ti's production was stopped with the introduction of the 4070 Ti
SUPER.[5]

### 12VHPWR connector
failures[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 12VHPWR connector failures")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Nvidia_12VHPWR_adapter.jpg/220px-
Nvidia_12VHPWR_adapter.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nvidia_12VHPWR_adapter.jpg)The Nvidia
12VHPWR adapter supplied with RTX 4090 cards

See also: [ATX § ATX 3.0](/wiki/ATX#ATX_3.0 "ATX")

This section is an excerpt from [16-pin 12VHPWR connector § RTX
4090](/wiki/16-pin_12VHPWR_connector#RTX_4090 "16-pin 12VHPWR
connector").[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=16-pin_12VHPWR_connector&action=edit)]

Some buyers of the Nvidia RTX 4090, the first GPU to use the new connector,
reported that the connectors of their RTX 4090 were melting,[51] which sparked
several theories to explain it. After investigation, several sources reported
that the main cause was the 12VHPWR connector not being fully seated while
being put under load that resulted in overheating of the connector's pins,
which in turn caused the melting of the plastic housing.[52][53]

[PCI-SIG](/wiki/PCI-SIG "PCI-SIG"), the [standards
organization](/wiki/Standards_organization "Standards organization")
responsible for the creation of the 12VHPWR connector, has decided to make
changes to the connector's specifications following the failures.[54]

A [class-action lawsuit](/wiki/Class_action "Class action") has been filed
against Nvidia over melting 12VHPWR cables which the lawsuit states is "a
dangerous product that should not have been sold in its current state."[55]
The plaintiff who brought the suit claims that Nvidia unjustly enriched
itself, violated the product's warranty and engaged in fraud and they are
demanding that Nvidia pay damages to affected customers as compensation.[56]

Following its own investigation and testing, Nvidia officially offered a
statement on the melting connectors. They determined that the melting
connectors are a cause of user error from not inserting the 12VHPWR connector
properly, causing partial contact. They have offered an expedited RMA process
for any RTX 4090 affected by the melting connectors.[57][58][59] PCI-SIG later
said in a statement that Nvidia and their partners were still responsible for
testing their products to account for user error.[60]

### US Export restrictions on the
4090[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: US Export restrictions on the 4090")]

The [United States Department of
Commerce](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Commerce "United States Department
of Commerce") began enacting restrictions on the Nvidia RTX 4090 for export to
certain countries in 2023.[61][62][63] This was targeted mainly towards China
as an attempt to halt its AI development. However as a result of this, the
market price of the 4090 rose by 25% as China began to stockpile 4090s.[64]
This led to Nvidia releasing a China specific model of the RTX 4090 called the
RTX 4090D (D standing for "Dragon").[65] The RTX 4090D features a shaved down
AD102 die with 14592 CUDA cores, down from 16384 cores of the original
4090.

[61][62][63] This was targeted mainly towards China
as an attempt to halt its AI development. However as a result of this, the
market price of the 4090 rose by 25% as China began to stockpile 4090s.[64]
This led to Nvidia releasing a China specific model of the RTX 4090 called the
RTX 4090D (D standing for "Dragon").[65] The RTX 4090D features a shaved down
AD102 die with 14592 CUDA cores, down from 16384 cores of the original
4090.[66]

The restrictions began on November 17th, 2023, effectively banning the 4090
from China and other countries on the export restricted list.[61]

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Reception")]

### RTX
4090[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: RTX 4090")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/NVIDIA_RTX_4090_Founders_Edition_-
_Verpackung_%28ZMASLO%29.png/220px-NVIDIA_RTX_4090_Founders_Edition_-
_Verpackung_%28ZMASLO%29.png)](/wiki/File:NVIDIA_RTX_4090_Founders_Edition_-
_Verpackung_\(ZMASLO\).png)RTX 4090 Founders Edition in its packaging
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/RTX4090_FE_PCB_and_die.jpg/220px-
RTX4090_FE_PCB_and_die.jpg)](/wiki/File:RTX4090_FE_PCB_and_die.jpg)RTX 4090
Founders Edition PCB

Upon release, the RTX 4090's performance received praise from reviewers with
_[Tom's Hardware](/wiki/Tom%27s_Hardware "Tom's Hardware")_ saying "it now
ranks among the best graphics cards".[67] A review by _[PC
Gamer](/wiki/PC_Gamer "PC Gamer")_ gave it 83/100, calling it "a hell of an
introduction to the sort of extreme performance Ada can deliver when given a
long leash".[68] Tom Warren in a review for _[The Verge](/wiki/The_Verge "The
Verge")_ said that the RTX 4090 is "a beast of a graphics card that marks a
new era for PC gaming".[69] John Loeffler from _[GamesRadar](/wiki/GamesRadar
"GamesRadar")_ wrote that the RTX 4090 offers "an incredible gen-on-gen
performance improvement over the RTX 3090", "even putting the Nvidia GeForce
RTX 3090 Ti to shame" and being "too powerful for a lot of gamers to really
take advantage of."[70] Aside from gaming performance,
_[PCWorld](/wiki/PC_World "PC World")_ 's review highlighted the RTX 4090's
benefits for content creators and streamers with its 24GB VRAM and
[AV1](/wiki/AV1 "AV1") encoding ability and was positive towards the Founders
Edition's quiet operation and cooling ability.[71]

However, it also received criticism for its value proposition given that it
begins at $1,599.[69] Analysis by _TechSpot_ found that the RTX 4090's value
at 1440p was worse than the RTX 3090 Ti and that the RTX 4090 did not make
much sense for 1440p as it was limited by CPU bottlenecks.[72] Power
consumption was another point of criticism for the RTX 4090.[72] The RTX 4090
has a TDP of 450W compared to the 350W of its last generation equivalent.
However, Jarred Walton of _Tom's Hardware_ noted that the RTX 4090 has the
same 450W TDP as the RTX 3090 Ti while delivering much higher performance with
that power consumption.[67]

However, it also received criticism for its value proposition given that it
begins at $1,599.[69] Analysis by _TechSpot_ found that the RTX 4090's value
at 1440p was worse than the RTX 3090 Ti and that the RTX 4090 did not make
much sense for 1440p as it was limited by CPU bottlenecks.[72] Power
consumption was another point of criticism for the RTX 4090.[72] The RTX 4090
has a TDP of 450W compared to the 350W of its last generation equivalent.
However, Jarred Walton of _Tom's Hardware_ noted that the RTX 4090 has the
same 450W TDP as the RTX 3090 Ti while delivering much higher performance with
that power consumption.[67]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/RTX4090_die.jpg/220px-
RTX4090_die.jpg)](/wiki/File:RTX4090_die.jpg)RTX 4090 die (AD102-300-A1)

Aftermarket AIB RTX 4090 variants received criticism in particular for their
massive cooler sizes with some models being 4 PCIe slots tall. This made it
difficult to fit an RTX 4090 into many mainstream PC cases.[73][74] YouTube
reviewer JayzTwoCents showed an Asus ROG Strix RTX 4090 model being comparable
in size to an entire [PlayStation 5](/wiki/PlayStation_5 "PlayStation 5")
console.[75] Another comparison showed Nvidia's RTX 4090 Founders Edition next
to the [Xbox Series X](/wiki/Xbox_Series_X/S "Xbox Series X/S") for size.[76]
It was theorized that a reason for the massive coolers on some models is that
the RTX 4090 was originally designed to have a TDP up to 600W before it was
reduced to its official 450W TDP.[77]

### RTX
4080[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: RTX 4080")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Size_comparison_between_RTX_3090_and_RTX_4090.jpg/220px-
Size_comparison_between_RTX_3090_and_RTX_4090.jpg)](/wiki/File:Size_comparison_between_RTX_3090_and_RTX_4090.jpg)An
aftermarket AIB variant of the RTX 4090 (Asus ROG Strix) on the bottom, next
to an RTX 3090 (Gigabyte Gaming OC) for size comparison

The RTX 4080 received more mixed reviews when compared to the RTX 4090.
_TechSpot_ gave the RTX 4080 score of 80/100.[78] Antony Leather of _Forbes_
found that the RTX 4080 consistently performed better than the RTX 3090
Ti.[79] The GPU's power efficiency was positively received with _Digital
Trends_ finding that the GPU had an average power draw of 271W despite its
rated 320W TDP.[80]

The RTX 4080's $1199 price received criticism for its dramatic increase from
that of the RTX 3080. In his review for _RockPaperShotgun_ , James Archer
wrote that the RTX 4080 "produces sizeable gains on the RTX 3080, though
they're not exactly proportional to the price rise".[81] In another critique,
_RockPaperShotgun_ highlighted that AIB models can significantly exceed the
base $1199 Founders Edition price, creating further value considerations. The
Asus ROG Strix AIB model they reviewed came in at $1550 which is $50 less than
the RTX 4090 Founders Edition.[81] Tom Warren of _The Verge_ recommended
waiting to see what [AMD](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced Micro
Devices") could deliver in performance and value with their [RDNA
3](/wiki/RDNA_\(microarchitecture\)#RDNA_3 "RDNA \(microarchitecture\)")
GPUs.[82] AMD's direct competitor, the [Radeon](/wiki/Radeon "Radeon") [RX
7900 XTX](/wiki/Radeon_RX_7000_series "Radeon RX 7000 series"), comes in at
$999 compared to the $1199 price of the RTX 4080.

The
Asus ROG Strix AIB model they reviewed came in at $1550 which is $50 less than
the RTX 4090 Founders Edition.[81] Tom Warren of _The Verge_ recommended
waiting to see what [AMD](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced Micro
Devices") could deliver in performance and value with their [RDNA
3](/wiki/RDNA_\(microarchitecture\)#RDNA_3 "RDNA \(microarchitecture\)")
GPUs.[82] AMD's direct competitor, the [Radeon](/wiki/Radeon "Radeon") [RX
7900 XTX](/wiki/Radeon_RX_7000_series "Radeon RX 7000 series"), comes in at
$999 compared to the $1199 price of the RTX 4080.

The RTX 4080 received criticism for reusing the RTX 4090's massive 4-slot
coolers which are not required to cool the RTX 4080's 320W TDP.[83][84] A
smaller cooler would have been sufficient. The RTX 3080 and RTX 3080 Ti with
their respective 320W and 350W TDPs maintained 2-slot coolers while the 320W
RTX 4080 has a 3-slot cooler on the Founders Edition and 4-slots on many AIB
models.[82]

It was reported that RTX 4080 sales were quite weak compared to the RTX 4090,
which had shockingly sold out during its launch a month earlier.[85] The
[global cost of living crisis](/wiki/Cost_of_living "Cost of living") and the
RTX 4080's generational pricing increase have been suggested as major
contributing factors for poor sales numbers.[86]

### RTX 4070
Ti[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: RTX 4070 Ti")]

Following its relaunch as the RTX 4070 Ti, the GPU received mixed reviews.
While its good thermal, 1080p, and 1440p performance were praised, its 4K
performance is considered weak for the high $800 price tag.

Jacob Roach from Digital Trends gave the RTX 4070 Ti a 6/10, criticizing the
lower memory bandwidth compared to the RTX 4080, its worse 4K performance, and
the lack of a Founder's Edition model, with fears that the board partner cards
would sell for over the $800 price tag, although he did praise the thermal
performance and efficiency of his unit.[87]

Michael Justin Allen Sexton from PCMag reviewed the [ZOTAC](/wiki/ZOTAC
"ZOTAC") RTX 4070 Ti Amp Extreme Airo model, giving it a 3.5/5, criticizing
the large size of the card and it being only $100 less than AMD's direct
competitor, the [Radeon](/wiki/Radeon "Radeon") [RX 7900
XT](/wiki/Radeon_RX_7000_series "Radeon RX 7000 series"), which comes in at
$899 compared to the $799 price of the RTX 4070 Ti.[88]

It was reported that RTX 4070 Ti sales were quite weak, similar to the RTX
4080 at launch.[89]

### RTX
4070[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: RTX 4070")]

At launch, Jacob Roach from Digital Trends gave the RTX 4070 a 4.5/5, praising
its efficiency, the fact the Founder's Edition only took up two slots, and its
good GPU performance at 1440p.[90] However, following the launch of the AMD
[Radeon RX 7800 XT](/wiki/Radeon_RX_7000_series "Radeon RX 7000 series"),
AMD's direct competitor to the RTX 4070, Monica J. White from Digital Trends
compared the latter to the RTX 4070, and said she would recommend the 7800 XT
over the RTX 4070 because of better rasterization performance at 1440p, the
fact that the 7800 XT had 16GB of VRAM compared to 12GB on the RTX 4070, and
that the 7800 XT had a $100 cheaper price.

[90] However, following the launch of the AMD
[Radeon RX 7800 XT](/wiki/Radeon_RX_7000_series "Radeon RX 7000 series"),
AMD's direct competitor to the RTX 4070, Monica J. White from Digital Trends
compared the latter to the RTX 4070, and said she would recommend the 7800 XT
over the RTX 4070 because of better rasterization performance at 1440p, the
fact that the 7800 XT had 16GB of VRAM compared to 12GB on the RTX 4070, and
that the 7800 XT had a $100 cheaper price.[91]

After the launch of AMD's Radeon RX 7800 XT, the direct competitor to the RTX
4070, which was released on September 6, 2023, the price of some RTX 4070
cards was lowered to $550 and the official MSRP was lowered to $550 following
the launch of the SUPER series.[92][93]

### RTX 4060 Ti (8 GB & 16
GB)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: RTX 4060 Ti \(8 GB & 16 GB\)")]

The RTX 4060 Ti 8GB released in late May 2023. Many reviewers and customers
denounced Nvidia for the lack of appropriate video memory for the release of
the card, pointing that the RTX 3060 of the previous generation was released
with 12GB of VRAM. Furthermore, many reviews mentioned that an 8GB card was
simply not enough for modern standards, for example Digital Trends saying "It
makes sense for the upcoming RTX 4060, which is launching in July with 8GB of
VRAM for $300, but not for the $400 RTX 4060 Ti. At this price and
performance, it should have 16GB of memory, or at the very least, a larger bus
size."[94] A few weeks later, prompted by consumers backlash, Nvidia announced
they would release the RTX 4060 Ti 16GB in July 2023.

Despite that, the release of the 16GB variant itself was met with suspicion.
Nvidia did not send samples for review, including to big names such as Gamers
Nexus, [Hardware Unboxed](https://www.youtube.com/@Hardwareunboxed), and
[Linus Tech Tips](/wiki/Linus_Tech_Tips "Linus Tech Tips"). It was also later
found out that AIBs were also prevented, presumably by Nvidia, to be allowed
to give cards out for reviews. According to Gamesradar: "Coming in at $499,
the Nvidia RTX 4060 Ti 16GB is arguably a hard sell. Normally, we’d test
whether the GPU offers bang for buck, but it looks like reviews aren’t going
to be a thing. In a way, that sort of makes sense, as it should perform fairly
similarly to the existing 8GB model, with the added benefit of more VRAM."[95]

YouTube reviewers Hardware Unboxed criticized both models of the RTX 4060 Ti,
calling the 8GB of VRAM model "laughably bad at $400" and "frankly, we don't
even need to test the RTX 4060 Ti 8GB to tell you it's a disgustingly poor
value product...". They criticized its 8GB of VRAM, which led to poor 1% low
frame rates at 1080p and unusable 1% low frame rates at 1440p in games such as
_[The Last of Us Part I](/wiki/The_Last_of_Us_Part_I "The Last of Us Part I")_
and _[The Callisto Protocol](/wiki/The_Callisto_Protocol "The Callisto
Protocol")_ both using the ultra quality preset. _[A Plague Tale:
Requiem](/wiki/A_Plague_Tale:_Requiem "A Plague Tale: Requiem")_ was also
unusable at 1080p not only using the ultra quality preset with ray tracing
enabled, but using the high quality preset with ray tracing enabled as it
suffered similar unusable 1% low performance.

They criticized its 8GB of VRAM, which led to poor 1% low
frame rates at 1080p and unusable 1% low frame rates at 1440p in games such as
_[The Last of Us Part I](/wiki/The_Last_of_Us_Part_I "The Last of Us Part I")_
and _[The Callisto Protocol](/wiki/The_Callisto_Protocol "The Callisto
Protocol")_ both using the ultra quality preset. _[A Plague Tale:
Requiem](/wiki/A_Plague_Tale:_Requiem "A Plague Tale: Requiem")_ was also
unusable at 1080p not only using the ultra quality preset with ray tracing
enabled, but using the high quality preset with ray tracing enabled as it
suffered similar unusable 1% low performance. While _[Halo
Infinite](/wiki/Halo_Infinite "Halo Infinite")_ and
_[Forspoken](/wiki/Forspoken "Forspoken")_ did not have poor 1% low
performance at 1080p, they instead sometimes failed to load textures with the
8GB RTX 4060 Ti due to a lack of VRAM.[96] These were not an issue with the
16GB RTX 4060 Ti, however, the 16GB RTX 4060 Ti was criticized for costing
$500 to "fix" the issues with running out of VRAM, which was $100 more than
the 8GB RTX 4060 Ti for otherwise identical performance outside of VRAM
limitations.[97]

### RTX
4060[[edit](/w/index.php?title=GeForce_40_series&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: RTX 4060")]

Jacob Roach from Digital Trends gave the RTX 4060 a 3/5, criticizing the poor
performance of the GPU for the price, its low 8GB of VRAM capacity, the slow
memory interface, and its performance at 1440p, although its efficiency was
praised. He stated: "In the past, the RTX 4060 would have been classified as a
workhorse GPU... The RTX 4060 falls short of filling that post, offering solid
generational improvements but middling competitive performance, and relying on
DLSS 3 and ray tracing to find its value."[98]

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

This article is about the business model for making [integrated
circuits](/wiki/Integrated_circuits "Integrated circuits"). For other uses of
the term **foundry** , see [foundry
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Foundry_\(disambiguation\) "Foundry
\(disambiguation\)").

Microelectronics engineering and manufacturing business model

The **foundry model** is a [microelectronics](/wiki/Microelectronics
"Microelectronics") engineering and manufacturing [business
model](/wiki/Business_model "Business model") consisting of a [semiconductor
fabrication plant](/wiki/Semiconductor_fabrication_plant "Semiconductor
fabrication plant"), or foundry, and an [integrated circuit
design](/wiki/Integrated_circuit_design "Integrated circuit design")
operation, each belonging to separate companies or subsidiaries.[1][2][3][4]

[Integrated device manufacturers](/wiki/Integrated_device_manufacturer
"Integrated device manufacturer") (IDMs) design and manufacture integrated
circuits. Many companies, known as [fabless semiconductor
companies](/wiki/Fabless_semiconductor_company "Fabless semiconductor
company"), only design devices; merchant or [pure play](/wiki/Pure_play "Pure
play") foundries only manufacture devices for other companies, without
designing them. Examples of IDMs are [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel"),
[Samsung](/wiki/Samsung_Electronics "Samsung Electronics"), and [Texas
Instruments](/wiki/Texas_Instruments "Texas Instruments"), examples of pure
play foundries are [GlobalFoundries](/wiki/GlobalFoundries "GlobalFoundries"),
[TSMC](/wiki/TSMC "TSMC"), and [UMC](/wiki/United_Microelectronics_Corporation
"United Microelectronics Corporation"), and examples of fabless companies are
[AMD](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced Micro Devices"),
[Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia"), and [Qualcomm](/wiki/Qualcomm "Qualcomm").

Integrated circuit production facilities are expensive to build and maintain.
Unless they can be kept at nearly full use, they will become a drain on the
[finances](/wiki/Finances "Finances") of the company that owns them. The
foundry [model](/wiki/Business_model "Business model") uses two methods to
avoid these costs: fabless companies avoid costs by not owning such
facilities. Merchant foundries, on the other hand, find work from the
worldwide pool of fabless companies, through careful
[scheduling](/wiki/Scheduling_\(production_processes\) "Scheduling
\(production processes\)"), [pricing](/wiki/Pricing "Pricing"), and
contracting, keep their plants in full use.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foundry_model&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

Companies that both designed and produced the devices were originally
responsible for manufacturing microelectronic devices. These manufacturers
were involved in both the [research and
development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") of
manufacturing processes and the research and development of
[microcircuit](/wiki/Microcircuit "Microcircuit") design.

Merchant foundries, on the other hand, find work from the
worldwide pool of fabless companies, through careful
[scheduling](/wiki/Scheduling_\(production_processes\) "Scheduling
\(production processes\)"), [pricing](/wiki/Pricing "Pricing"), and
contracting, keep their plants in full use.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foundry_model&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

Companies that both designed and produced the devices were originally
responsible for manufacturing microelectronic devices. These manufacturers
were involved in both the [research and
development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") of
manufacturing processes and the research and development of
[microcircuit](/wiki/Microcircuit "Microcircuit") design.

The first pure play semiconductor company is the [Taiwan Semiconductor
Manufacturing
Corporation](/wiki/Taiwan_Semiconductor_Manufacturing_Corporation "Taiwan
Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation"), a [spin-off](/wiki/Corporate_spin-
off "Corporate spin-off") of the government [Industrial Technology Research
Institute](/wiki/Industrial_Technology_Research_Institute "Industrial
Technology Research Institute"), which split its design and fabrication
divisions in 1987,[5] a model advocated for by [Carver Mead](/wiki/Carver_Mead
"Carver Mead") in the U.S., but deemed too costly to pursue. The separation of
design and fabrication became known as the foundry model, with [fabless
manufacturing](/wiki/Fabless_manufacturing "Fabless manufacturing")
outsourcing to [semiconductor foundries](/wiki/Semiconductor_foundry
"Semiconductor foundry").[6]

[Fabless semiconductor companies](/wiki/Fabless_semiconductor_companies
"Fabless semiconductor companies") do not have any semiconductor fabrication
capability; and contract production with a merchant foundry manufacturer. The
fabless company concentrates on the research and development of an IC-product;
the foundry concentrates on manufacturing and [testing](/wiki/Test_method
"Test method") the physical product. If the foundry does not have any
semiconductor design capability, it is a pure-play semiconductor foundry.

An absolute separation into fabless and foundry companies is not necessary.
Some companies continue to exist that perform both operations and benefit from
the close coupling of their skills. Some companies manufacture some of their
own designs and contract out to have others manufactured or designed, in cases
where they see [value](/wiki/Value_\(marketing\) "Value \(marketing\)") or
seek special skills. The foundry model is a business vision that seeks to
optimize productivity.

### MOSIS[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foundry_model&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: MOSIS")]

The very first merchant foundries were part of the [MOSIS](/wiki/MOSIS
"MOSIS") service. The MOSIS service gave limited production access to
designers with limited means, such as students, university researchers, and
engineers at small [startups](/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company").[7] The
designer submitted designs, and these submissions were manufactured with the
commercial company's extra capacity. Manufacturers could insert some
[wafers](/wiki/Wafer_\(electronics\) "Wafer \(electronics\)") for a MOSIS
design into a collection of their own wafers when a processing step was
compatible with both operations. The commercial company (serving as foundry)
was already running the process, so they were effectively being paid by MOSIS
for something they were already doing. A factory with excess capacity during
slow periods could also run MOSIS designs to avoid having expensive
[capital](/wiki/Capital_\(economics\) "Capital \(economics\)") equipment stand
idle.

Under-use of an expensive manufacturing plant could lead to the financial ruin
of the owner, so selling surplus [wafer](/wiki/Wafer_\(electronics\) "Wafer
\(electronics\)") capacity was a way to maximize the fab's use. Hence,
economic factors created a climate where fab operators wanted to sell surplus
wafer-manufacturing capacity and designers wanted to purchase manufacturing
capacity rather than try to build it.

Although MOSIS opened the doors to some fabless customers, earning additional
[revenue](/wiki/Revenue "Revenue") for the foundry and providing inexpensive
service to the customer, running a business around MOSIS production was
difficult. The merchant foundries sold wafer capacity on a surplus basis, as a
secondary business activity.

Under-use of an expensive manufacturing plant could lead to the financial ruin
of the owner, so selling surplus [wafer](/wiki/Wafer_\(electronics\) "Wafer
\(electronics\)") capacity was a way to maximize the fab's use. Hence,
economic factors created a climate where fab operators wanted to sell surplus
wafer-manufacturing capacity and designers wanted to purchase manufacturing
capacity rather than try to build it.

Although MOSIS opened the doors to some fabless customers, earning additional
[revenue](/wiki/Revenue "Revenue") for the foundry and providing inexpensive
service to the customer, running a business around MOSIS production was
difficult. The merchant foundries sold wafer capacity on a surplus basis, as a
secondary business activity. Services to the customers were secondary to the
commercial business, with little [guarantee](/wiki/Guarantee "Guarantee") of
support. The choice of merchant dictated the design, development flow, and
available techniques to the fabless customer. Merchant foundries might require
[proprietary](/wiki/Property "Property") and non-portable preparation steps.
Foundries concerned with protecting what they considered [trade
secrets](/wiki/Trade_secret "Trade secret") of their
[methodologies](/wiki/Methodologies "Methodologies") might only be willing to
release data to designers after an onerous
[nondisclosure](/wiki/Nondisclosure_agreement "Nondisclosure agreement")
procedure.

### Dedicated
foundry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foundry_model&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Dedicated foundry")]

In 1987, the world's first dedicated merchant foundry opened its doors:
[Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC)](/wiki/TSMC "TSMC").[8] The
distinction of 'dedicated' is in reference to the typical merchant foundry of
the era, whose primary business activity was building and selling of its own
[IC](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit")-products. The dedicated
foundry offers several key advantages to its customers: first, it does not
sell finished IC-products into the [supply](/wiki/Supply_\(economics\) "Supply
\(economics\)") channel; thus a dedicated foundry will never compete directly
with its fabless customers (obviating a common concern of fabless companies).
Second, the dedicated foundry can scale production capacity to a customer's
needs, offering low-quantity [shuttle](/wiki/Multi-project_wafer_service
"Multi-project wafer service") services in addition to full-scale
[production](/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production") lines. Finally, the
dedicated foundry offers a "COT-flow" (customer owned tooling) based on
industry-standard [EDA](/wiki/Electronic_design_automation "Electronic design
automation") systems, whereas many IDM merchants required its customers to use
proprietary (non-portable) development tools. The COT advantage gave the
customer complete control over the design process, from concept to final
design.

## Financial and IP
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foundry_model&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Financial and IP issues")]

Like all industries, the semiconductor industry faces upcoming challenges and
obstacles.

The cost to stay on the leading edge has steadily increased with each
generation of chips. The financial strain is being felt by both large merchant
foundries and their fabless customers. The cost of a new foundry exceeds $1
billion. These costs must be passed on to customers. Many merchant foundries
have entered into joint ventures with their competitors in an effort to split
research and design expenditures and fab-maintenance expenses.

Chip design companies sometimes avoid other companies' patents simply by
purchasing the products from a licensed foundry with broad cross-license
agreements with the patent owner.[23]

Stolen design data is also a concern; data is rarely directly copied, because
blatant copies are easily identified by distinctive features in the chip,[24]
placed there either for this purpose or as a byproduct of the design process.
However, the data including any procedure, process system, method of operation
or concept may be sold to a competitor, who may save months or years of
tedious [reverse engineering](/wiki/Reverse_engineering "Reverse
engineering").

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Specialized electronic circuit; graphics accelerator

"GPU" redirects here. For other uses, see [GPU
(disambiguation)](/wiki/GPU_\(disambiguation\) "GPU \(disambiguation\)").

For an expansion card that contains a graphics processing unit, see [graphics
card](/wiki/Graphics_card "Graphics card").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Generic_block_diagram_of_a_GPU.svg/530px-
Generic_block_diagram_of_a_GPU.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Generic_block_diagram_of_a_GPU.svg)Components
of a GPU

A **graphics processing unit** ( **GPU** ) is a specialized [electronic
circuit](/wiki/Electronic_circuit "Electronic circuit") initially designed to
accelerate [computer graphics](/wiki/Computer_graphics "Computer graphics")
and [image processing](/wiki/Image_processing "Image processing") (either on a
[video card](/wiki/Video_card "Video card") or embedded on
[motherboards](/wiki/Motherboard "Motherboard"), [mobile
phones](/wiki/Mobile_phone "Mobile phone"), [personal
computers](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer"),
[workstations](/wiki/Workstation "Workstation"), and [game
consoles](/wiki/Game_console "Game console")). After their initial design,
GPUs were found to be useful for non-graphic calculations involving
[embarrassingly parallel](/wiki/Embarrassingly_parallel "Embarrassingly
parallel") problems due to their [parallel structure](/wiki/Parallel_computing
"Parallel computing"). Other non-graphical uses include the training of
[neural networks](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network#Training "Artificial neural
network") and [cryptocurrency mining](/wiki/Cryptocurrency#Mining
"Cryptocurrency").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

See also: [Video display controller](/wiki/Video_display_controller "Video
display controller"), [List of home computers by video

graphics)](/wiki/Sprite_\(computer_graphics\) "Sprite \(computer graphics\)")

###
1970s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 1970s")]

[Arcade system boards](/wiki/Arcade_system_board "Arcade system board") have
used specialized graphics circuits since the 1970s. In early video game
hardware, [RAM](/wiki/Random-access_memory "Random-access memory") for frame
buffers was expensive, so video chips composited data together as the display
was being scanned out on the monitor.

In early video game
hardware, [RAM](/wiki/Random-access_memory "Random-access memory") for frame
buffers was expensive, so video chips composited data together as the display
was being scanned out on the monitor.[1]

A specialized [barrel shifter](/wiki/Barrel_shifter "Barrel shifter") circuit
helped the CPU animate the [framebuffer](/wiki/Framebuffer "Framebuffer")
graphics for various 1970s [arcade video games](/wiki/Arcade_video_game
"Arcade video game") from [Midway](/wiki/Midway_Games "Midway Games") and
[Taito](/wiki/Taito "Taito"), such as _[Gun Fight](/wiki/Gun_Fight "Gun
Fight")_ (1975), _[Sea Wolf](/wiki/Sea_Wolf_\(video_game\) "Sea Wolf \(video
game\)")_ (1976), and _[Space Invaders](/wiki/Space_Invaders "Space
Invaders")_ (1978).[2] The [Namco Galaxian](/wiki/Namco_Galaxian "Namco
Galaxian") arcade system in 1979 used specialized [graphics
hardware](/wiki/Graphics_hardware "Graphics hardware") that supported [RGB
color](/wiki/RGB_color_model "RGB color model"), multi-colored sprites, and
[tilemap](/wiki/Tile_engine "Tile engine") backgrounds.[3] The Galaxian
hardware was widely used during the [golden age of arcade video
games](/wiki/Golden_age_of_arcade_video_games "Golden age of arcade video
games"), by game companies such as [Namco](/wiki/Namco "Namco"),
[Centuri](/wiki/Centuri "Centuri"), [Gremlin](/wiki/Gremlin_Industries
"Gremlin Industries"), [Irem](/wiki/Irem "Irem"), [Konami](/wiki/Konami
"Konami"), Midway, [Nichibutsu](/wiki/Nichibutsu "Nichibutsu"),
[Sega](/wiki/Sega "Sega"), and Taito.[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/ANTIC_chip_on_an_Atari_130XE_motherboard.jpg/220px-
ANTIC_chip_on_an_Atari_130XE_motherboard.jpg)](/wiki/File:ANTIC_chip_on_an_Atari_130XE_motherboard.jpg)Atari
[ANTIC](/wiki/ANTIC "ANTIC") microprocessor on an Atari 130XE motherboard

The [Atari 2600](/wiki/Atari_2600 "Atari 2600") in 1977 used a video shifter
called the [Television Interface Adaptor](/wiki/Television_Interface_Adaptor
"Television Interface Adaptor").[5] [Atari 8-bit
computers](/wiki/Atari_8-bit_family "Atari 8-bit family") (1979) had
[ANTIC](/wiki/ANTIC "ANTIC"), a video processor which interpreted instructions
describing a "[display list](/wiki/Display_list "Display list")"—the way the
scan lines map to specific [bitmapped](/wiki/Bitmapped "Bitmapped") or
character modes and where the memory is stored (so there did not need to be a
contiguous frame buffer).[ _[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_ ][6]
[6502](/wiki/6502 "6502") [machine code](/wiki/Machine_code "Machine code")
[subroutines](/wiki/Subroutine "Subroutine") could be triggered on [scan
lines](/wiki/Scan_line "Scan line") by setting a bit on a display list
instruction.[ _[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_ ][7] ANTIC also supported smooth
[vertical](/wiki/Vertical_scrolling "Vertical scrolling") and [horizontal
scrolling](/wiki/Horizontal_scrolling "Horizontal scrolling") independent of
the CPU.[8]

###
1980s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1980s")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/NEC_D7220.jpg/220px-
NEC_D7220.jpg)](/wiki/File:NEC_D7220.jpg)NEC [μPD7220](/wiki/%CE%9CPD7220
"ΜPD7220")A

The [NEC µPD7220](/wiki/NEC_%C2%B5PD7220 "NEC µPD7220") was the first
implementation of a [personal computer](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal
computer") graphics display processor as a single [large-scale
integration](/wiki/Large-scale_integration "Large-scale integration") (LSI)
[integrated circuit](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit") chip. This
enabled the design of low-cost, high-performance video graphics cards such as
those from [Number Nine Visual Technology](/wiki/Number_Nine_Visual_Technology
"Number Nine Visual Technology"). It became the best-known GPU until the
mid-1980s.[9] It was the first fully integrated [VLSI](/wiki/VLSI "VLSI")
(very large-scale integration)
[metal–oxide–semiconductor](/wiki/Metal%E2%80%93oxide%E2%80%93semiconductor
"Metal–oxide–semiconductor") ([NMOS](/wiki/NMOS_logic "NMOS logic")) graphics
display processor for PCs, supported up to [1024×1024 resolution](/wiki/XGA
"XGA"), and laid the foundations for the emerging PC graphics market. It was
used in a number of graphics cards and was licensed for clones such as the
Intel 82720, the first of [Intel's graphics processing
units](/wiki/List_of_Intel_graphics_processing_units "List of Intel graphics
processing units").[10] The Williams Electronics arcade games _[Robotron
2084](/wiki/Robotron_2084 "Robotron 2084")_ ,
_[Joust](/wiki/Joust_\(video_game\) "Joust \(video game\)")_ ,
_[Sinistar](/wiki/Sinistar "Sinistar")_ , and
_[Bubbles](/wiki/Bubbles_\(video_game\) "Bubbles \(video game\)")_ , all
released in 1982, contain custom [blitter](/wiki/Blitter "Blitter") chips for
operating on 16-color bitmaps.[11][12]

In 1984, [Hitachi](/wiki/Hitachi "Hitachi") released ARTC HD63484, the first
major [CMOS](/wiki/CMOS "CMOS") graphics processor for personal computers. The
ARTC could display up to [4K resolution](/wiki/4K_resolution "4K resolution")
when in [monochrome](/wiki/Monochrome "Monochrome") mode. It was used in a
number of graphics cards and terminals during the late 1980s.[13] In 1985, the
[Amiga](/wiki/Amiga "Amiga") was released with a custom graphics chip
including a [blitter](/wiki/Blitter "Blitter") for bitmap manipulation, line
drawing, and area fill. It also included a [coprocessor](/wiki/Coprocessor
"Coprocessor") with its own simple instruction set, that was capable of
manipulating graphics hardware registers in sync with the video beam (e.g. for
per-scanline palette switches, sprite multiplexing, and hardware windowing),
or driving the blitter. In 1986, [Texas Instruments](/wiki/Texas_Instruments
"Texas Instruments") released the [TMS34010](/wiki/TMS34010 "TMS34010"), the
first fully programmable graphics processor.[14] It could run general-purpose
code, but it had a graphics-oriented instruction set.

It also included a [coprocessor](/wiki/Coprocessor
"Coprocessor") with its own simple instruction set, that was capable of
manipulating graphics hardware registers in sync with the video beam (e.g. for
per-scanline palette switches, sprite multiplexing, and hardware windowing),
or driving the blitter. In 1986, [Texas Instruments](/wiki/Texas_Instruments
"Texas Instruments") released the [TMS34010](/wiki/TMS34010 "TMS34010"), the
first fully programmable graphics processor.[14] It could run general-purpose
code, but it had a graphics-oriented instruction set. During 1990–1992, this
chip became the basis of the [Texas Instruments Graphics
Architecture](/wiki/Texas_Instruments_Graphics_Architecture "Texas Instruments
Graphics Architecture") ("TIGA") [Windows
accelerator](/wiki/Windows_accelerator "Windows accelerator") cards.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/IBM_8514.jpg/220px-
IBM_8514.jpg)](/wiki/File:IBM_8514.jpg)The [IBM 8514](/wiki/IBM_8514 "IBM
8514") Micro Channel adapter, with memory add-on

In 1987, the [IBM 8514](/wiki/IBM_8514 "IBM 8514") graphics system was
released. It was one of the first video cards for [IBM PC
compatibles](/wiki/IBM_PC_compatible "IBM PC compatible") to implement [fixed-
function](/wiki/Fixed-function "Fixed-function") 2D primitives in [electronic
hardware](/wiki/Electronic_hardware "Electronic hardware").
[Sharp](/wiki/Sharp_Corporation "Sharp Corporation")'s [X68000](/wiki/X68000
"X68000"), released in 1987, used a custom graphics chipset[15] with a 65,536
color palette and hardware support for sprites, scrolling, and multiple
playfields.[16] It served as a development machine for [Capcom](/wiki/Capcom
"Capcom")'s [CP System](/wiki/CP_System "CP System") arcade board. Fujitsu's
[FM Towns](/wiki/FM_Towns "FM Towns") computer, released in 1989, had support
for a 16,777,216 color palette.[17] In 1988, the first dedicated [polygonal
3D](/wiki/3D_computer_graphics "3D computer graphics") graphics boards were
introduced in arcades with the [Namco System 21](/wiki/Namco_System_21 "Namco
System 21")[18] and [Taito](/wiki/Taito "Taito") Air System.[19]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/IBM_VGA_90X8941_on_PS55.jpg/220px-
IBM_VGA_90X8941_on_PS55.jpg)](/wiki/File:IBM_VGA_90X8941_on_PS55.jpg)[VGA](/wiki/Video_Graphics_Array
"Video Graphics Array") section on the motherboard in [IBM
PS/55](/wiki/IBM_Personal_System/55 "IBM Personal System/55")

[IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") introduced its [proprietary](/wiki/Proprietary_software
"Proprietary software") [Video Graphics Array](/wiki/Video_Graphics_Array
"Video Graphics Array") (VGA) display standard in 1987, with a maximum
resolution of 640×480 pixels. In November 1988, [NEC Home
Electronics](/wiki/NEC "NEC") announced its creation of the [Video Electronics
Standards Association](/wiki/Video_Electronics_Standards_Association "Video
Electronics Standards Association") (VESA) to develop and promote a [Super
VGA](/wiki/Super_video_graphics_array "Super video graphics array") (SVGA)
[computer display standard](/wiki/Computer_display_standard "Computer display
standard") as a successor to VGA. Super VGA enabled [graphics display
resolutions](/wiki/Graphics_display_resolution "Graphics display resolution")
up to 800×600 [pixels](/wiki/Pixel "Pixel"), a 36% increase.[20]
