### 1990s
[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1990s")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Dstealth32.jpg/220px-
Dstealth32.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dstealth32.jpg)[Tseng Labs](/wiki/Tseng_Labs
"Tseng Labs") [ET4000/W32p](/wiki/Tseng_Labs_ET4000 "Tseng Labs ET4000")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/DIAMONDSTEALTH3D2000-top.JPG/220px-
DIAMONDSTEALTH3D2000-top.JPG)](/wiki/File:DIAMONDSTEALTH3D2000-top.JPG)[S3
Graphics](/wiki/S3_Graphics "S3 Graphics") [ViRGE](/wiki/S3_ViRGE "S3 ViRGE")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Voodoo3-2000AGP.jpg/220px-
Voodoo3-2000AGP.jpg)](/wiki/File:Voodoo3-2000AGP.jpg)[Voodoo3](/wiki/Voodoo3
"Voodoo3") 2000 AGP card

In 1991, [S3 Graphics](/wiki/S3_Graphics "S3 Graphics") introduced the _[S3
86C911](/wiki/S3_Graphics "S3 Graphics")_ , which its designers named after
the [Porsche 911](/wiki/Porsche_911 "Porsche 911") as an indication of the
performance increase it promised.[21] The 86C911 spawned a host of imitators:
by 1995, all major PC graphics chip makers had added
[2D](/wiki/2D_computer_graphics "2D computer graphics") acceleration support
to their chips.[22] Fixed-function _Windows accelerators_ surpassed expensive
general-purpose graphics coprocessors in Windows performance, and such
coprocessors faded from the PC market.

Throughout the 1990s, 2D [GUI](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user
interface") acceleration evolved. As manufacturing capabilities improved, so
did the level of integration of graphics chips. Additional [application
programming interfaces](/wiki/Application_programming_interface "Application
programming interface") (APIs) arrived for a variety of tasks, such as
Microsoft's [WinG](/wiki/WinG "WinG") [graphics
library](/wiki/Graphics_library "Graphics library") for [Windows
3.x](/wiki/Windows_3.1x "Windows 3.1x"), and their later
[DirectDraw](/wiki/DirectDraw "DirectDraw") interface for [hardware
acceleration](/wiki/Hardware_acceleration "Hardware acceleration") of 2D games
in [Windows 95](/wiki/Windows_95 "Windows 95") and later.

In the early- and mid-1990s, [real-time](/wiki/Real-time_computer_graphics
"Real-time computer graphics") 3D graphics became increasingly common in
arcade, computer, and console games, which led to increasing public demand for
hardware-accelerated 3D graphics.

In the early- and mid-1990s, [real-time](/wiki/Real-time_computer_graphics
"Real-time computer graphics") 3D graphics became increasingly common in
arcade, computer, and console games, which led to increasing public demand for
hardware-accelerated 3D graphics. Early examples of mass-market 3D graphics
hardware can be found in arcade system boards such as the [Sega Model
1](/wiki/Sega_Model_1 "Sega Model 1"), [Namco System 22](/wiki/Namco_System_22
"Namco System 22"), and [Sega Model 2](/wiki/Sega_Model_2 "Sega Model 2"), and
the [fifth-generation video game
consoles](/wiki/History_of_video_game_consoles_\(fifth_generation\) "History
of video game consoles \(fifth generation\)") such as the
[Saturn](/wiki/Sega_Saturn "Sega Saturn"), [PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation
"PlayStation"), and [Nintendo 64](/wiki/Nintendo_64 "Nintendo 64"). Arcade
systems such as the Sega Model 2 and [SGI](/wiki/Silicon_Graphics "Silicon
Graphics") [Onyx](/wiki/SGI_Onyx "SGI Onyx")-based Namco Magic Edge Hornet
Simulator in 1993 were capable of hardware T&L ([transform, clipping, and
lighting](/wiki/Transform,_clipping,_and_lighting "Transform, clipping, and
lighting")) years before appearing in consumer graphics cards.[23][24] Another
early example is the [Super FX](/wiki/Super_FX "Super FX") chip, a
[RISC](/wiki/Reduced_instruction_set_computer "Reduced instruction set
computer")-based [on-cartridge graphics
chip](/wiki/ROM_cartridge#Use_in_hardware_enhancements "ROM cartridge") used
in some [SNES](/wiki/Super_Nintendo_Entertainment_System "Super Nintendo
Entertainment System") games, notably
_[Doom](/wiki/List_of_Doom_ports#Super_NES "List of Doom ports")_ and _[Star
Fox](/wiki/Star_Fox_\(1993_video_game\) "Star Fox \(1993 video game\)")_. Some
systems used [DSPs](/wiki/Digital_signal_processor "Digital signal processor")
to accelerate transformations. [Fujitsu](/wiki/Fujitsu "Fujitsu"), which
worked on the Sega Model 2 arcade system,[25] began working on integrating T&L
into a single [LSI](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit") solution
for use in home computers in 1995;[26] the Fujitsu Pinolite, the first 3D
geometry processor for personal computers, released in 1997.[27] The first
hardware T&L GPU on [home](/wiki/Home_console "Home console") [video game
consoles](/wiki/Video_game_console "Video game console") was the [Nintendo
64](/wiki/Nintendo_64 "Nintendo 64")'s [Reality
Coprocessor](/wiki/Reality_Coprocessor "Reality Coprocessor"), released in
1996.[28] In 1997, [Mitsubishi](/wiki/Mitsubishi "Mitsubishi") released the
[3Dpro/2MP](/wiki/AMD_FirePro "AMD FirePro"), a GPU capable of transformation
and lighting, for [workstations](/wiki/Workstation "Workstation") and [Windows
NT](/wiki/Windows_NT "Windows NT") desktops;[29] [ATi](/wiki/ATi "ATi") used
it for its [FireGL 4000](/wiki/FireGL "FireGL") [graphics
card](/wiki/Graphics_card "Graphics card"), released in 1997.[30]

The term "GPU" was coined by [Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony") in reference to the
32-bit [Sony GPU](/wiki/PlayStation_technical_specifications "PlayStation
technical specifications") (designed by [Toshiba](/wiki/Toshiba "Toshiba")) in
the [PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation_\(console\) "PlayStation \(console\)")
video game console, released in 1994.

[30]

The term "GPU" was coined by [Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony") in reference to the
32-bit [Sony GPU](/wiki/PlayStation_technical_specifications "PlayStation
technical specifications") (designed by [Toshiba](/wiki/Toshiba "Toshiba")) in
the [PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation_\(console\) "PlayStation \(console\)")
video game console, released in 1994.[31]

In the PC world, notable failed attempts for low-cost 3D graphics chips
included the [S3](/wiki/S3_Graphics "S3 Graphics") _[ViRGE](/wiki/ViRGE
"ViRGE")_ , [ATI Rage](/wiki/ATI_Rage "ATI Rage"), and [Matrox](/wiki/Matrox
"Matrox") _Mystique_. These chips were essentially previous-generation 2D
accelerators with 3D features bolted on. Many were [pin-compatible](/wiki/Pin-
compatibility "Pin-compatibility") with the earlier-generation chips for ease
of implementation and minimal cost. Initially, 3D graphics were possible only
with discrete boards dedicated to accelerating 3D functions (and lacking 2D
graphical user interface (GUI) acceleration entirely) such as the
[PowerVR](/wiki/PowerVR "PowerVR") and the [3dfx](/wiki/3dfx "3dfx") _Voodoo_.
However, as manufacturing technology continued to progress, video, 2D GUI
acceleration, and 3D functionality were all integrated into one chip.
[Rendition's](/wiki/Rendition_\(company\) "Rendition \(company\)") _Verite_
chipsets were among the first to do this well. In 1997, Rendition collaborated
with [Hercules](/wiki/Hercules_Computer_Technology "Hercules Computer
Technology") and Fujitsu on a "Thriller Conspiracy" project which combined a
Fujitsu FXG-1 Pinolite geometry processor with a Vérité V2200 core to create a
graphics card with a full T&L engine years before Nvidia's [GeForce
256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce 256"); This card, designed to reduce the load
placed upon the system's CPU, never made it to market.[ _[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ] NVIDIA
[RIVA 128](/wiki/RIVA_128 "RIVA 128") was one of the first consumer-facing GPU
integrated 3D processing unit and 2D processing unit on a chip.

[OpenGL](/wiki/OpenGL "OpenGL") appeared in the early '90s as a professional
graphics API, but originally suffered from performance issues which allowed
the [Glide API](/wiki/Glide_API "Glide API") to become a dominant force on the
PC in the late '90s.[32] These issues were quickly overcome and the Glide API
fell by the wayside. Software implementations of OpenGL were common during
this time, although the influence of OpenGL eventually led to widespread
hardware support. [DirectX](/wiki/DirectX "DirectX") became popular among
[Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows") game developers during
the late '90s. Unlike OpenGL, Microsoft insisted on providing strict one-to-
one support of hardware. The approach made DirectX less popular as a
standalone graphics API initially, since many GPUs provided their own specific
features, which existing OpenGL applications were already able to benefit
from, leaving DirectX often one generation behind. (See: [Comparison of OpenGL
and Direct3D](/wiki/Comparison_of_OpenGL_and_Direct3D "Comparison of OpenGL
and Direct3D").)

Microsoft began to work more closely with hardware developers and started to
target the releases of DirectX to coincide with those of the supporting
graphics hardware. [Direct3D](/wiki/Direct3D "Direct3D") 5.0 was the first
version of the API to gain widespread adoption in the gaming market, and it
competed directly with more-hardware-specific, often proprietary, graphics
libraries, while OpenGL maintained a strong following. Direct3D 7.0 introduced
support for hardware-accelerated [transform and
lighting](/wiki/Transform_and_lighting "Transform and lighting") (T&L) for
Direct3D; OpenGL had this capability from its inception.

(See: [Comparison of OpenGL
and Direct3D](/wiki/Comparison_of_OpenGL_and_Direct3D "Comparison of OpenGL
and Direct3D").)

Microsoft began to work more closely with hardware developers and started to
target the releases of DirectX to coincide with those of the supporting
graphics hardware. [Direct3D](/wiki/Direct3D "Direct3D") 5.0 was the first
version of the API to gain widespread adoption in the gaming market, and it
competed directly with more-hardware-specific, often proprietary, graphics
libraries, while OpenGL maintained a strong following. Direct3D 7.0 introduced
support for hardware-accelerated [transform and
lighting](/wiki/Transform_and_lighting "Transform and lighting") (T&L) for
Direct3D; OpenGL had this capability from its inception. 3D accelerator cards
moved beyond being simple [rasterizers](/wiki/Rasterisation "Rasterisation")
to add another significant hardware stage to the 3D rendering pipeline. The
[Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia") _[GeForce 256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce
256")_ (also known as NV10) was the first consumer-level card with hardware-
accelerated T&L; professional 3D cards already had this capability. Hardware
transform and lighting—existing features of OpenGL—came to consumer-level
hardware in the '90s and set the precedent for later [pixel
shader](/wiki/Pixel_shader "Pixel shader") and [vertex
shader](/wiki/Vertex_shader "Vertex shader") units which were far more
flexible and programmable.

###
2000s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 2000s")]

Nvidia was first to produce a chip capable of programmable
[shading](/wiki/Pixel_shader "Pixel shader"): the _[GeForce 3](/wiki/GeForce_3
"GeForce 3")_. Each pixel could now be processed by a short program that could
include additional image textures as inputs, and each geometric vertex could
likewise be processed by a short program before it was projected onto the
screen. Used in the [Xbox](/wiki/Xbox "Xbox") console, this chip competed with
the one in the [PlayStation 2](/wiki/PlayStation_2 "PlayStation 2"), which
used a custom vector unit for hardware accelerated vertex processing (commonly
referred to as VU0/VU1). The earliest incarnations of shader execution engines
used in [Xbox](/wiki/Xbox "Xbox") were not general purpose and could not
execute arbitrary pixel code. Vertices and pixels were processed by different
units which had their own resources, with pixel shaders having tighter
constraints (because they execute at higher frequencies than vertices). Pixel
shading engines were actually more akin to a highly customizable function
block and did not really "run" a program. Many of these disparities between
vertex and pixel shading were not addressed until the [Unified Shader
Model](/wiki/Unified_Shader_Model "Unified Shader Model").

In October 2002, with the introduction of the [ATI](/wiki/ATI_Technologies
"ATI Technologies") _[Radeon 9700](/wiki/Radeon_9700_core "Radeon 9700 core")_
(also known as R300), the world's first [Direct3D](/wiki/Direct3D "Direct3D")
9.0 accelerator, pixel and vertex shaders could implement
[looping](/wiki/Loop_\(computing\) "Loop \(computing\)") and lengthy [floating
point](/wiki/Floating_point "Floating point") math, and were quickly becoming
as flexible as CPUs, yet orders of magnitude faster for image-array
operations. Pixel shading is often used for [bump mapping](/wiki/Bump_mapping
"Bump mapping"), which adds texture to make an object look shiny, dull, rough,
or even round or extruded.[33]

With the introduction of the Nvidia [GeForce 8 series](/wiki/GeForce_8_series
"GeForce 8 series") and new generic stream processing units, GPUs became more
generalized computing devices.

Pixel shading is often used for [bump mapping](/wiki/Bump_mapping
"Bump mapping"), which adds texture to make an object look shiny, dull, rough,
or even round or extruded.[33]

With the introduction of the Nvidia [GeForce 8 series](/wiki/GeForce_8_series
"GeForce 8 series") and new generic stream processing units, GPUs became more
generalized computing devices. [Parallel](/wiki/Parallel_computing "Parallel
computing") GPUs are making computational inroads against the CPU, and a
subfield of research, dubbed GPU computing or [GPGPU](/wiki/GPGPU "GPGPU") for
_general purpose computing on GPU_ , has found applications in fields as
diverse as [machine learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning"),[34]
[oil exploration](/wiki/Oil_exploration "Oil exploration"), scientific [image
processing](/wiki/Image_processing "Image processing"), [linear
algebra](/wiki/Linear_algebra "Linear algebra"),[35]
[statistics](/wiki/Statistics "Statistics"),[36] [3D
reconstruction](/wiki/3D_reconstruction "3D reconstruction"), and [stock
options](/wiki/Stock_options "Stock options") pricing. [GPGPU](/wiki/GPGPU
"GPGPU") was the precursor to what is now called a compute shader (e.g. CUDA,
OpenCL, DirectCompute) and actually abused the hardware to a degree by
treating the data passed to algorithms as texture maps and executing
algorithms by drawing a triangle or quad with an appropriate pixel shader.[
_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please
clarify")_ ] This entails some overheads since units like the [scan
converter](/wiki/Rasterization "Rasterization") are involved where they are
not needed (nor are triangle manipulations even a concern—except to invoke the
pixel shader).[ _[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_ ]

Nvidia's [CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA") platform, first introduced in 2007,[37] was
the earliest widely adopted programming model for GPU computing.
[OpenCL](/wiki/OpenCL "OpenCL") is an open standard defined by the [Khronos
Group](/wiki/Khronos_Group "Khronos Group") that allows for the development of
code for both GPUs and CPUs with an emphasis on portability.[38] OpenCL
solutions are supported by Intel, AMD, Nvidia, and ARM, and according to a
report in 2011 by Evans Data, OpenCL had become the second most popular HPC
tool.[39]

###
2010s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 2010s")]

In 2010, Nvidia partnered with [Audi](/wiki/Audi "Audi") to power their cars'
dashboards, using the [Tegra](/wiki/Tegra "Tegra") GPU to provide increased
functionality to cars' navigation and entertainment systems.[40] Advances in
GPU technology in cars helped advance [self-driving
technology](/wiki/Autonomous_car "Autonomous car").[41] AMD's [Radeon HD 6000
series](/wiki/Radeon_HD_6000_series "Radeon HD 6000 series") cards were
released in 2010, and in 2011 AMD released its 6000M Series discrete GPUs for
mobile devices.[42] The Kepler line of graphics cards by Nvidia were released
in 2012 and were used in the Nvidia's 600 and 700 series cards. A feature in
this GPU microarchitecture included GPU boost, a technology that adjusts the
clock-speed of a video card to increase or decrease it according to its power
draw.[43] The [Kepler microarchitecture](/wiki/Kepler_\(microarchitecture\)
"Kepler \(microarchitecture\)") was manufactured on the [28 nm
process](/wiki/28_nm_process "28 nm process")[ _[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_ ].

The [PS4](/wiki/PlayStation_4_technical_specifications "PlayStation 4
technical specifications") and [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One") were
released in 2013; they both use GPUs based on [AMD's Radeon HD 7850 and
7790](/wiki/Radeon_HD_7000_series "Radeon HD 7000 series").

A feature in
this GPU microarchitecture included GPU boost, a technology that adjusts the
clock-speed of a video card to increase or decrease it according to its power
draw.[43] The [Kepler microarchitecture](/wiki/Kepler_\(microarchitecture\)
"Kepler \(microarchitecture\)") was manufactured on the [28 nm
process](/wiki/28_nm_process "28 nm process")[ _[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_ ].

The [PS4](/wiki/PlayStation_4_technical_specifications "PlayStation 4
technical specifications") and [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One") were
released in 2013; they both use GPUs based on [AMD's Radeon HD 7850 and
7790](/wiki/Radeon_HD_7000_series "Radeon HD 7000 series").[44] Nvidia's
Kepler line of GPUs was followed by the
[Maxwell](/wiki/Maxwell_\(microarchitecture\) "Maxwell \(microarchitecture\)")
line, manufactured on the same process. Nvidia's 28 nm chips were manufactured
by [TSMC](/wiki/TSMC "TSMC") in Taiwan using the 28 nm process. Compared to
the 40 nm technology from the past, this manufacturing process allowed a 20
percent boost in performance while drawing less power.[45][46] [Virtual
reality headsets](/wiki/Virtual_reality_headset "Virtual reality headset")
have high system requirements; manufacturers recommended the GTX 970 and the
R9 290X or better at the time of their release.[47][48] Cards based on the
[Pascal](/wiki/Pascal_\(microarchitecture\) "Pascal \(microarchitecture\)")
microarchitecture were released in 2016. The [GeForce 10
series](/wiki/GeForce_10_series "GeForce 10 series") of cards are of this
generation of graphics cards. They are made using the 16 nm manufacturing
process which improves upon previous microarchitectures.[49] Nvidia released
one non-consumer card under the new [Volta](/wiki/Volta_\(microarchitecture\)
"Volta \(microarchitecture\)") architecture, the Titan V. Changes from the
Titan XP, Pascal's high-end card, include an increase in the number of CUDA
cores, the addition of tensor cores, and [HBM2](/wiki/High_Bandwidth_Memory
"High Bandwidth Memory"). Tensor cores are designed for deep learning, while
high-bandwidth memory is on-die, stacked, lower-clocked memory that offers an
extremely wide memory bus. To emphasize that the Titan V is not a gaming card,
Nvidia removed the "GeForce GTX" suffix it adds to consumer gaming cards.

In 2018, Nvidia launched the RTX 20 series GPUs that added ray-tracing cores
to GPUs, improving their performance on lighting effects.[50] [Polaris
11](/wiki/Polaris_11 "Polaris 11") and [Polaris 10](/wiki/Polaris_10 "Polaris
10") GPUs from AMD are fabricated by a 14 nm process. Their release resulted
in a substantial increase in the performance per watt of AMD video cards.[51]
AMD also released the Vega GPU series for the high end market as a competitor
to Nvidia's high end Pascal cards, also featuring HBM2 like the Titan V.

In 2019, AMD released the successor to their [Graphics Core
Next](/wiki/Graphics_Core_Next "Graphics Core Next") (GCN)
microarchitecture/instruction set. Dubbed RDNA, the first product featuring it
was the [Radeon RX 5000 series](/wiki/Radeon_RX_5000_series "Radeon RX 5000
series") of video cards.[52]

The company announced that the successor to the RDNA microarchitecture would
be incremental (aka a refresh). AMD unveiled the [Radeon RX 6000
series](/wiki/Radeon_RX_6000_series "Radeon RX 6000 series"), its RDNA 2
graphics cards with support for hardware-accelerated ray tracing.[53] The
product series, launched in late 2020, consisted of the RX 6800, RX 6800 XT,
and RX 6900 XT.[54][55] The RX 6700 XT, which is based on Navi 22, was
launched in early 2021.

Dubbed RDNA, the first product featuring it
was the [Radeon RX 5000 series](/wiki/Radeon_RX_5000_series "Radeon RX 5000
series") of video cards.[52]

The company announced that the successor to the RDNA microarchitecture would
be incremental (aka a refresh). AMD unveiled the [Radeon RX 6000
series](/wiki/Radeon_RX_6000_series "Radeon RX 6000 series"), its RDNA 2
graphics cards with support for hardware-accelerated ray tracing.[53] The
product series, launched in late 2020, consisted of the RX 6800, RX 6800 XT,
and RX 6900 XT.[54][55] The RX 6700 XT, which is based on Navi 22, was
launched in early 2021.[56]

The [PlayStation 5](/wiki/PlayStation_5 "PlayStation 5") and [Xbox Series X
and Series S](/wiki/Xbox_Series_X_and_Series_S "Xbox Series X and Series S")
were released in 2020; they both use GPUs based on the [RDNA 2](/wiki/RDNA_2
"RDNA 2") microarchitecture with incremental improvements and different GPU
configurations in each system's implementation.[57][58][59]

[Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel") first [entered the GPU
market](/wiki/List_of_Intel_graphics_processing_units "List of Intel graphics
processing units") in the late 1990s, but produced lackluster 3D accelerators
compared to the competition at the time. Rather than attempting to compete
with the high-end manufacturers Nvidia and ATI/AMD, they began integrating
[Intel Graphics Technology](/wiki/Intel_Graphics_Technology "Intel Graphics
Technology") GPUs into motherboard chipsets, beginning with the [Intel
810](/wiki/Intel_810 "Intel 810") for the Pentium III, and later into CPUs.
They began with the [Intel Atom
'Pineview'](/wiki/Bonnell_\(microarchitecture\)#Pineview "Bonnell
\(microarchitecture\)") laptop processor in 2009, continuing in 2010 with
desktop processors in the first generation of the [Intel
Core](/wiki/Intel_Core "Intel Core") line and with contemporary Pentiums and
Celerons. This resulted in a large nominal market share, as the majority of
computers with an Intel CPU also featured this embedded graphics processor.
These generally lagged behind discrete processors in performance. Intel re-
entered the discrete GPU market in 2022 with its [Arc](/wiki/Intel_Arc "Intel
Arc") series, which competed with the then-current GeForce 30 series and
Radeon 6000 series cards at competitive prices.[ _[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ]

###
2020s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 2020s")]

See also: [AI accelerator](/wiki/AI_accelerator "AI accelerator")

In the 2020s, GPUs have been increasingly used for calculations involving
[embarrassingly parallel](/wiki/Embarrassingly_parallel "Embarrassingly
parallel") problems, such as training of [neural
networks](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network#Training "Artificial neural
network") on enormous datasets that are needed for [large language
models](/wiki/Large_language_model "Large language model"). Specialized
processing cores on some modern workstation's GPUs are dedicated for [deep
learning](/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning") since they have significant
FLOPS performance increases, using 4×4 matrix multiplication and division,
resulting in hardware performance up to 128 TFLOPS in some applications.[60]
These tensor cores are expected to appear in consumer cards, as well.[ _[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_ ][61]

## Computational
functions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Computational functions")]

Modern GPUs have traditionally used most of their
[transistors](/wiki/Transistor "Transistor") to do calculations related to [3D
computer graphics](/wiki/3D_computer_graphics "3D computer graphics"). In
addition to the 3D hardware, today's GPUs include basic 2D acceleration and
[framebuffer](/wiki/Framebuffer "Framebuffer") capabilities (usually with a
VGA compatibility mode). Newer cards such as AMD/ATI HD5000–HD7000 lack
dedicated 2D acceleration; it is emulated by 3D hardware. GPUs were initially
used to accelerate the memory-intensive work of [texture
mapping](/wiki/Texture_mapping "Texture mapping") and
[rendering](/wiki/Rendering_\(computer_graphics\) "Rendering \(computer
graphics\)") polygons. Later, units[ _[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_ ] were
added to accelerate [geometric](/wiki/Geometry "Geometry") calculations such
as the [rotation](/wiki/Rotation "Rotation") and
[translation](/wiki/Translation_\(geometry\) "Translation \(geometry\)") of
[vertices](/wiki/Vertex_\(geometry\) "Vertex \(geometry\)") into different
[coordinate systems](/wiki/Coordinate_system "Coordinate system"). Recent
developments in GPUs include support for [programmable
shaders](/wiki/Programmable_shader "Programmable shader") which can manipulate
vertices and textures with many of the same operations that are supported by
[CPUs](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing unit"),
[oversampling](/wiki/Oversampling "Oversampling") and
[interpolation](/wiki/Interpolation "Interpolation") techniques to reduce
[aliasing](/wiki/Aliasing "Aliasing"), and very high-precision [color
spaces](/wiki/Color_space "Color space").

Several factors of GPU construction affect the performance of the card for
real-time rendering, such as the size of the connector pathways in the
[semiconductor device fabrication](/wiki/Semiconductor_device_fabrication
"Semiconductor device fabrication"), the [clock signal](/wiki/Clock_signal
"Clock signal") frequency, and the number and size of various on-chip memory
[caches](/wiki/CPU_cache "CPU cache").

Several factors of GPU construction affect the performance of the card for
real-time rendering, such as the size of the connector pathways in the
[semiconductor device fabrication](/wiki/Semiconductor_device_fabrication
"Semiconductor device fabrication"), the [clock signal](/wiki/Clock_signal
"Clock signal") frequency, and the number and size of various on-chip memory
[caches](/wiki/CPU_cache "CPU cache"). Performance is also affected by the
number of streaming multiprocessors (SM) for NVidia GPUs, or compute units
(CU) for AMD GPUs, or Xe cores for Intel discrete GPUs, which describe the
number of core on-silicon processor units within the GPU chip that perform the
core calculations, typically working in parallel with other SM/CUs on the GPU.
GPU performance is typically measured in floating point operations per second
([FLOPS](/wiki/FLOPS "FLOPS")); GPUs in the 2010s and 2020s typically deliver
performance measured in teraflops (TFLOPS). This is an estimated performance
measure, as other factors can affect the actual display rate.[63]

### GPU accelerated video decoding and
encoding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: GPU accelerated video decoding and encoding")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/AMD_HD5470_GPU.JPG/220px-
AMD_HD5470_GPU.JPG)](/wiki/File:AMD_HD5470_GPU.JPG)The ATI HD5470 GPU (above,
with copper [heatpipe](/wiki/Heatpipe "Heatpipe") attached) features
[UVD](/wiki/UVD "UVD") 2.1 which enables it to decode AVC and VC-1 video
formats.

Most GPUs made since 1995 support the [YUV](/wiki/YUV "YUV") [color
space](/wiki/Color_space "Color space") and [hardware
overlays](/wiki/Hardware_overlay "Hardware overlay"), important for [digital
video](/wiki/Digital_video "Digital video") playback, and many GPUs made since
2000 also support [MPEG](/wiki/MPEG "MPEG") primitives such as [motion
compensation](/wiki/Motion_compensation "Motion compensation") and
[iDCT](/wiki/Inverse_discrete_cosine_transform "Inverse discrete cosine
transform"). This hardware-accelerated video decoding, in which portions of
the [video decoding](/wiki/Video_decoding "Video decoding") process and [video
post-processing](/wiki/Video_post-processing "Video post-processing") are
offloaded to the GPU hardware, is commonly referred to as "GPU accelerated
video decoding", "GPU assisted video decoding", "GPU hardware accelerated
video decoding", or "GPU hardware assisted video decoding".

Recent graphics cards decode [high-definition video](/wiki/High-
definition_video "High-definition video") on the card, offloading the central
processing unit. The most common [APIs](/wiki/API "API") for GPU accelerated
video decoding are [DxVA](/wiki/DirectX_Video_Acceleration "DirectX Video
Acceleration") for [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft
Windows") operating systems and [VDPAU](/wiki/VDPAU "VDPAU"),
[VAAPI](/wiki/VaAPI "VaAPI"), [XvMC](/wiki/X-Video_Motion_Compensation
"X-Video Motion Compensation"), and
[XvBA](/wiki/X-Video_Bitstream_Acceleration "X-Video Bitstream Acceleration")
for Linux-based and UNIX-like operating systems.

Recent graphics cards decode [high-definition video](/wiki/High-
definition_video "High-definition video") on the card, offloading the central
processing unit. The most common [APIs](/wiki/API "API") for GPU accelerated
video decoding are [DxVA](/wiki/DirectX_Video_Acceleration "DirectX Video
Acceleration") for [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft
Windows") operating systems and [VDPAU](/wiki/VDPAU "VDPAU"),
[VAAPI](/wiki/VaAPI "VaAPI"), [XvMC](/wiki/X-Video_Motion_Compensation
"X-Video Motion Compensation"), and
[XvBA](/wiki/X-Video_Bitstream_Acceleration "X-Video Bitstream Acceleration")
for Linux-based and UNIX-like operating systems. All except XvMC are capable
of decoding videos encoded with [MPEG-1](/wiki/MPEG-1 "MPEG-1"),
[MPEG-2](/wiki/MPEG-2 "MPEG-2"), [MPEG-4 ASP (MPEG-4 Part
2)](/wiki/MPEG-4_Part_2 "MPEG-4 Part 2"), [MPEG-4 AVC](/wiki/MPEG-4_AVC
"MPEG-4 AVC") (H.264 / DivX 6), [VC-1](/wiki/VC-1 "VC-1"), [WMV3](/wiki/WMV3
"WMV3")/[WMV9](/wiki/WMV9 "WMV9"), [Xvid](/wiki/Xvid "Xvid") / OpenDivX (DivX
4), and [DivX](/wiki/DivX "DivX") 5 [codecs](/wiki/Codec "Codec"), while XvMC
is only capable of decoding MPEG-1 and MPEG-2.

There are several [dedicated hardware video decoding and encoding
solutions](/wiki/Category:Video_compression_and_decompression_ASIC
"Category:Video compression and decompression ASIC").

#### Video decoding processes that can be
accelerated[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Video decoding processes that can be accelerated")]

Video decoding processes that can be accelerated by modern GPU hardware are:

  * [Motion compensation (mocomp)](/wiki/Motion_compensation "Motion compensation")
  * [Inverse discrete cosine transform (iDCT)](/wiki/Inverse_discrete_cosine_transform "Inverse discrete cosine transform")
    * [Inverse telecine](/wiki/Inverse_telecine "Inverse telecine") 3:2 and 2:2 pull-down correction
  * Inverse [modified discrete cosine transform](/wiki/Modified_discrete_cosine_transform "Modified discrete cosine transform") (iMDCT)
  * In-loop [deblocking filter](/wiki/Deblocking_filter_\(video\) "Deblocking filter \(video\)")
  * Intra-frame prediction
  * Inverse [quantization](/wiki/Quantization_\(image_processing\) "Quantization \(image processing\)") (IQ)
  * [Variable-length decoding (VLD)](/wiki/Huffman_coding "Huffman coding"), more commonly known as slice-level acceleration
  * Spatial-temporal [deinterlacing](/wiki/Deinterlacing "Deinterlacing") and automatic [interlace](/wiki/Interlaced_video "Interlaced video")/[progressive](/wiki/Progressive_scan "Progressive scan") source detection
  * Bitstream processing ([Context-adaptive variable-length coding](/wiki/Context-adaptive_variable-length_coding "Context-adaptive variable-length coding")/[Context-adaptive binary arithmetic coding](/wiki/Context-adaptive_binary_arithmetic_coding "Context-adaptive binary arithmetic coding")) and perfect pixel positioning

These operations also have applications in video editing, encoding, and
transcoding.

### 2D graphics
APIs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: 2D graphics APIs")]

An earlier GPU may support one or more 2D graphics API for 2D acceleration,
such as [GDI](/wiki/Graphics_Device_Interface "Graphics Device Interface") and
[DirectDraw](/wiki/DirectDraw "DirectDraw").

### 2D graphics
APIs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: 2D graphics APIs")]

An earlier GPU may support one or more 2D graphics API for 2D acceleration,
such as [GDI](/wiki/Graphics_Device_Interface "Graphics Device Interface") and
[DirectDraw](/wiki/DirectDraw "DirectDraw").[64]

### 3D graphics
APIs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: 3D graphics APIs")]

A GPU can support one or more 3D graphics API, such as [DirectX](/wiki/DirectX
"DirectX"), [Metal](/wiki/Metal_\(API\) "Metal \(API\)"),
[OpenGL](/wiki/OpenGL "OpenGL"), [OpenGL ES](/wiki/OpenGL_ES "OpenGL ES"),
[Vulkan](/wiki/Vulkan "Vulkan").

## GPU
forms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: GPU forms")]

###
Terminology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Terminology")]

In the 1970s, the term "GPU" originally stood for _graphics processor unit_
and described a programmable processing unit working independently from the
CPU that was responsible for graphics manipulation and output.[65][66] In
1994, [Sony](/wiki/Sony "Sony") used the term (now standing for _graphics
processing unit_ ) in reference to the
[PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation_\(console\) "PlayStation \(console\)")
console's [Toshiba](/wiki/Toshiba "Toshiba")-designed [Sony
GPU](/wiki/PlayStation_technical_specifications#Graphics_processing_unit_\(GPU\)
"PlayStation technical specifications").[31] The term was popularized by
[Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia") in 1999, who marketed the [GeForce
256](/wiki/GeForce_256 "GeForce 256") as "the world's first GPU".[67] It was
presented as a "single-chip [processor](/wiki/Processor_\(computing\)
"Processor \(computing\)") with integrated [transform, lighting, triangle
setup/clipping](/wiki/Transform,_clipping,_and_lighting "Transform, clipping,
and lighting"), and rendering engines".[68] Rival [ATI
Technologies](/wiki/ATI_Technologies "ATI Technologies") coined the term "
**visual processing unit** " or **VPU** with the release of the [Radeon
9700](/wiki/R300 "R300") in 2002.[69] The [AMD Alveo MA35D](/wiki/Xilinx
"Xilinx") features dual VPU’s, each using the [5 nm
process](/wiki/5_nm_process "5 nm process") in 2023.[70]

In personal computers, there are two main forms of GPUs. Each has many
synonyms:[71]

  * _Dedicated graphics_ also called _discrete graphics_.
  * _Integrated graphics_ also called _shared graphics solutions_ , _integrated graphics processors_ (IGP), or _unified memory architecture_ (UMA).

### Dedicated graphics processing
unit[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Dedicated graphics processing unit")]

See also: [Video card](/wiki/Video_card "Video card")

_Dedicated graphics processing units_ are not necessarily removable, nor does
it necessarily interface with the motherboard in a standard fashion. The term
"dedicated" refers to the fact that [graphics cards](/wiki/Graphics_card
"Graphics card") have [RAM](/wiki/Random-access_memory "Random-access memory")
that is dedicated to the card's use, not to the fact that _most_ dedicated
GPUs are removable. This RAM is usually specially selected for the expected
serial workload of the graphics card (see [GDDR](/wiki/GDDR_SDRAM "GDDR
SDRAM")). Sometimes systems with dedicated _discrete_ GPUs were called "DIS"
systems as opposed to "UMA" systems (see next section).[72] Dedicated GPUs for
portable computers are most commonly interfaced through a non-standard and
often proprietary slot due to size and weight constraints. Such ports may
still be considered PCIe or AGP in terms of their logical host interface, even
if they are not physically interchangeable with their counterparts.

Graphics cards with dedicated GPUs typically interface with the
[motherboard](/wiki/Motherboard "Motherboard") by means of an [expansion
slot](/wiki/Expansion_slot "Expansion slot") such as [PCI
Express](/wiki/PCI_Express "PCI Express") (PCIe) or [Accelerated Graphics
Port](/wiki/Accelerated_Graphics_Port "Accelerated Graphics Port") (AGP). They
can usually be replaced or upgraded with relative ease, assuming the
motherboard is capable of supporting the upgrade. A few graphics cards still
use [Peripheral Component
Interconnect](/wiki/Peripheral_Component_Interconnect "Peripheral Component
Interconnect") (PCI) slots, but their bandwidth is so limited that they are
generally used only when a PCIe or AGP slot is not available.

Technologies such as [SLI](/wiki/Scalable_Link_Interface "Scalable Link
Interface") and [NVLink](/wiki/NVLink "NVLink") by Nvidia and
[CrossFire](/wiki/ATI_CrossFire "ATI CrossFire") by AMD allow multiple GPUs to
draw images simultaneously for a single screen, increasing the processing
power available for graphics. These technologies, however, are increasingly
uncommon; most games do not fully use multiple GPUs, as most users cannot
afford them.

They
can usually be replaced or upgraded with relative ease, assuming the
motherboard is capable of supporting the upgrade. A few graphics cards still
use [Peripheral Component
Interconnect](/wiki/Peripheral_Component_Interconnect "Peripheral Component
Interconnect") (PCI) slots, but their bandwidth is so limited that they are
generally used only when a PCIe or AGP slot is not available.

Technologies such as [SLI](/wiki/Scalable_Link_Interface "Scalable Link
Interface") and [NVLink](/wiki/NVLink "NVLink") by Nvidia and
[CrossFire](/wiki/ATI_CrossFire "ATI CrossFire") by AMD allow multiple GPUs to
draw images simultaneously for a single screen, increasing the processing
power available for graphics. These technologies, however, are increasingly
uncommon; most games do not fully use multiple GPUs, as most users cannot
afford them.[73][74][75] Multiple GPUs are still used on supercomputers (like
in [Summit](/wiki/Summit_\(supercomputer\) "Summit \(supercomputer\)")), on
workstations to accelerate video (processing multiple videos at
once)[76][77][78] and 3D rendering,[79] for VFX,[80] [GPGPU](/wiki/GPGPU
"GPGPU") workloads and for simulations,[81] and in AI to expedite training, as
is the case with Nvidia's lineup of DGX workstations and servers, Tesla GPUs,
and Intel's Ponte Vecchio GPUs.

### Integrated graphics processing
unit[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Integrated graphics processing unit")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Motherboard_diagram.svg/330px-
Motherboard_diagram.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Motherboard_diagram.svg)The position
of an integrated GPU in a northbridge/southbridge system layout
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/A790GXH-128M-Motherboard.jpg/330px-A790GXH-128M-Motherboard.jpg)](/wiki/File:A790GXH-128M-Motherboard.jpg)An
[ASRock](/wiki/ASRock "ASRock") motherboard with integrated graphics, which
has HDMI, VGA and DVI-out ports

_Integrated graphics processing unit_ (IGPU), _integrated graphics_ , _shared
graphics solutions_ , _integrated graphics processors_ (IGP), or _unified
memory architecture_ (UMA) use a portion of a computer's system RAM rather
than dedicated graphics memory. IGPs can be integrated onto a motherboard as
part of its [northbridge](/wiki/Northbridge_\(computing\) "Northbridge
\(computing\)") chipset,[82] or on the same [die (integrated
circuit)](/wiki/Die_\(integrated_circuit\) "Die \(integrated circuit\)") with
the CPU (like [AMD APU](/wiki/AMD_APU "AMD APU") or [Intel HD
Graphics](/wiki/Intel_HD_Graphics "Intel HD Graphics")). On certain
motherboards,[83] AMD's IGPs can use dedicated sideport memory: a separate
fixed block of high performance memory that is dedicated for use by the GPU.
As of early
2007[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit)
computers with integrated graphics account for about 90% of all PC
shipments.[84][ _[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_ ] They are less costly to
implement than dedicated graphics processing, but tend to be less capable.
Historically, integrated processing was considered unfit for 3D games or
graphically intensive programs but could run less intensive programs such as
Adobe Flash. Examples of such IGPs would be offerings from SiS and VIA circa
2004.[85] However, modern integrated graphics processors such as [AMD
Accelerated Processing Unit](/wiki/AMD_Accelerated_Processing_Unit "AMD
Accelerated Processing Unit") and [Intel Graphics
Technology](/wiki/Intel_Graphics_Technology "Intel Graphics Technology") (HD,
UHD, Iris, Iris Pro, Iris Plus, and [Xe-LP](/wiki/Intel_Xe#Xe-LP_\(Low_Power\)
"Intel Xe")) can handle 2D graphics or low-stress 3D graphics.

Historically, integrated processing was considered unfit for 3D games or
graphically intensive programs but could run less intensive programs such as
Adobe Flash. Examples of such IGPs would be offerings from SiS and VIA circa
2004.[85] However, modern integrated graphics processors such as [AMD
Accelerated Processing Unit](/wiki/AMD_Accelerated_Processing_Unit "AMD
Accelerated Processing Unit") and [Intel Graphics
Technology](/wiki/Intel_Graphics_Technology "Intel Graphics Technology") (HD,
UHD, Iris, Iris Pro, Iris Plus, and [Xe-LP](/wiki/Intel_Xe#Xe-LP_\(Low_Power\)
"Intel Xe")) can handle 2D graphics or low-stress 3D graphics.

Since GPU computations are memory-intensive, integrated processing may compete
with the CPU for relatively slow system RAM, as it has minimal or no dedicated
video memory. IGPs use system memory with bandwidth up to a current maximum of
128 GB/s, whereas a discrete graphics card may have a bandwidth of more than
1000 GB/s between its [VRAM](/wiki/Video_random_access_memory "Video random
access memory") and GPU core. This [memory bus](/wiki/Memory_bus "Memory bus")
bandwidth can limit the performance of the GPU, though [multi-channel
memory](/wiki/Multi-channel_memory_architecture "Multi-channel memory
architecture") can mitigate this deficiency.[86] Older integrated graphics
chipsets lacked hardware [transform and
lighting](/wiki/Transform,_clipping,_and_lighting "Transform, clipping, and
lighting"), but newer ones include it.[87][88]

On systems with "Unified Memory Architecture" (UMA), including modern AMD
processors with integrated graphics,[89] modern Intel processors with
integrated graphics,[90] Apple processors, the PS5 and Xbox Series (among
others), the CPU cores and the GPU block share the same pool of RAM and memory
address space. This allows the system to dynamically allocate memory between
the CPU cores and the GPU block based on memory needs (without needing a large
static split of the RAM) and thanks to zero copy transfers, removes the need
for either copying data over a [bus (computing)](/wiki/Bus_\(computing\) "Bus
\(computing\)") between physically separate RAM pools or copying between
separate address spaces on a single physical pool of RAM, allowing more
efficient transfer of data.

### Hybrid graphics
processing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Hybrid graphics processing")]

Hybrid GPUs compete with integrated graphics in the low-end desktop and
notebook markets. The most common implementations of this are ATI's
[HyperMemory](/wiki/HyperMemory "HyperMemory") and Nvidia's
[TurboCache](/wiki/TurboCache "TurboCache").

Hybrid graphics cards are somewhat more expensive than integrated graphics,
but much less expensive than dedicated graphics cards. They share memory with
the system and have a small dedicated memory cache, to make up for the high
[latency](/wiki/Memory_latency "Memory latency") of the system RAM.
Technologies within PCI Express make this possible. While these solutions are
sometimes advertised as having as much as 768 MB of RAM, this refers to how
much can be shared with the system memory.

### Stream processing and general purpose GPUs
(GPGPU)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Stream processing and general purpose GPUs \(GPGPU\)")]

Main articles: [GPGPU](/wiki/GPGPU "GPGPU") and [Stream
processing](/wiki/Stream_processing "Stream processing")

It is common to use a [general purpose graphics processing unit
(GPGPU)](/wiki/GPGPU "GPGPU") as a modified form of [stream
processor](/wiki/Stream_processing "Stream processing") (or a [vector
processor](/wiki/Vector_processor "Vector processor")), running [compute
kernels](/wiki/Compute_kernel "Compute kernel"). This turns the massive
computational power of a modern graphics accelerator's shader pipeline into
general-purpose computing power. In certain applications requiring massive
vector operations, this can yield several orders of magnitude higher
performance than a conventional CPU. The two largest discrete (see "Dedicated
graphics processing unit" above) GPU designers, [AMD](/wiki/AMD "AMD") and
[Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia"), are pursuing this approach with an array of
applications.

This turns the massive
computational power of a modern graphics accelerator's shader pipeline into
general-purpose computing power. In certain applications requiring massive
vector operations, this can yield several orders of magnitude higher
performance than a conventional CPU. The two largest discrete (see "Dedicated
graphics processing unit" above) GPU designers, [AMD](/wiki/AMD "AMD") and
[Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia"), are pursuing this approach with an array of
applications. Both Nvidia and AMD teamed with [Stanford
University](/wiki/Stanford_University "Stanford University") to create a GPU-
based client for the [Folding@home](/wiki/Folding@home "Folding@home")
distributed computing project for protein folding calculations. In certain
circumstances, the GPU calculates forty times faster than the CPUs
traditionally used by such applications.[91][92]

GPGPUs can be used for many types of [embarrassingly
parallel](/wiki/Embarrassingly_parallel "Embarrassingly parallel") tasks
including [ray tracing](/wiki/Ray_tracing_\(graphics\) "Ray tracing
\(graphics\)"). They are generally suited to high-throughput computations that
exhibit [data-parallelism](/wiki/Data-parallelism "Data-parallelism") to
exploit the wide vector width [SIMD](/wiki/SIMD "SIMD") architecture of the
GPU.

GPU-based high performance computers play a significant role in large-scale
modelling. Three of the ten most powerful supercomputers in the world take
advantage of GPU acceleration.[93]

GPUs support API extensions to the [C](/wiki/C_\(programming_language\) "C
\(programming language\)") programming language such as [OpenCL](/wiki/OpenCL
"OpenCL") and [OpenMP](/wiki/OpenMP "OpenMP"). Furthermore, each GPU vendor
introduced its own API which only works with their cards: [AMD APP
SDK](/wiki/AMD_APP_SDK "AMD APP SDK") from AMD, and [CUDA](/wiki/CUDA "CUDA")
from Nvidia. These allow functions called [compute
kernels](/wiki/Compute_kernel "Compute kernel") to run on the GPU's stream
processors. This makes it possible for C programs to take advantage of a GPU's
ability to operate on large buffers in parallel, while still using the CPU
when appropriate. CUDA was the first API to allow CPU-based applications to
directly access the resources of a GPU for more general purpose computing
without the limitations of using a graphics API.[ _[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_ ]

Since 2005 there has been interest in using the performance offered by GPUs
for [evolutionary computation](/wiki/Evolutionary_computation "Evolutionary
computation") in general, and for accelerating the
[fitness](/wiki/Fitness_\(genetic_algorithm\) "Fitness \(genetic algorithm\)")
evaluation in [genetic programming](/wiki/Genetic_programming "Genetic
programming") in particular. Most approaches compile
[linear](/wiki/Linear_genetic_programming "Linear genetic programming") or
[tree programs](/wiki/Genetic_programming "Genetic programming") on the host
PC and transfer the executable to the GPU to be run. Typically a performance
advantage is only obtained by running the single active program simultaneously
on many example problems in parallel, using the GPU's [SIMD](/wiki/SIMD
"SIMD") architecture.[94] However, substantial acceleration can also be
obtained by not compiling the programs, and instead transferring them to the
GPU, to be interpreted there.[95] Acceleration can then be obtained by either
interpreting multiple programs simultaneously, simultaneously running multiple
example problems, or combinations of both. A modern GPU can simultaneously
interpret hundreds of thousands of very small programs.

### External GPU
(eGPU)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: External GPU \(eGPU\)")]

An external GPU is a graphics processor located outside of the housing of the
computer, similar to a large external hard drive. External graphics processors
are sometimes used with laptop computers. Laptops might have a substantial
amount of RAM and a sufficiently powerful central processing unit (CPU), but
often lack a powerful graphics processor, and instead have a less powerful but
more energy-efficient on-board graphics chip. On-board graphics chips are
often not powerful enough for playing video games, or for other graphically
intensive tasks, such as editing video or 3D animation/rendering.

A modern GPU can simultaneously
interpret hundreds of thousands of very small programs.

### External GPU
(eGPU)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: External GPU \(eGPU\)")]

An external GPU is a graphics processor located outside of the housing of the
computer, similar to a large external hard drive. External graphics processors
are sometimes used with laptop computers. Laptops might have a substantial
amount of RAM and a sufficiently powerful central processing unit (CPU), but
often lack a powerful graphics processor, and instead have a less powerful but
more energy-efficient on-board graphics chip. On-board graphics chips are
often not powerful enough for playing video games, or for other graphically
intensive tasks, such as editing video or 3D animation/rendering.

Therefore, it is desirable to attach a GPU to some external bus of a notebook.
[PCI Express](/wiki/PCI_Express "PCI Express") is the only bus used for this
purpose. The port may be, for example, an [ExpressCard](/wiki/ExpressCard
"ExpressCard") or [mPCIe](/wiki/PCI_Express#PCI_Express_Mini_Card "PCI
Express") port (PCIe ×1, up to 5 or 2.5 Gbit/s respectively), a
[Thunderbolt](/wiki/Thunderbolt_\(interface\) "Thunderbolt \(interface\)") 1,
2, or 3 port (PCIe ×4, up to 10, 20, or 40 Gbit/s respectively), or an
[OCuLink](/wiki/OCuLink "OCuLink") port. Those ports are only available on
certain notebook systems.[96][97] eGPU enclosures include their own power
supply (PSU), because powerful GPUs can consume hundreds of watts.[98]

Official vendor support for external GPUs has gained traction. A milestone was
Apple's decision to support external GPUs with MacOS High Sierra 10.13.4.[99]
Several major hardware vendors (HP, Razer) released Thunderbolt 3 eGPU
enclosures.[100][101] This support fuels eGPU implementations by enthusiasts.[
_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please
clarify")_ ][102]

## Energy
efficiency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Graphics_processing_unit&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Energy efficiency")]

This section is an excerpt from [Performance per watt § GPU
efficiency](/wiki/Performance_per_watt#GPU_efficiency "Performance per
watt").[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Performance_per_watt&action=edit)]

Graphics processing units (GPU) have continued to increase in energy usage,
while CPUs designers have recently focused on improving performance per watt.
High performance GPUs may draw large amount of power, therefore intelligent
techniques are required to manage GPU power consumption. Measures like
[3DMark2006 score](/wiki/3DMark "3DMark") per watt can help identify more
efficient GPUs.[103] However that may not adequately incorporate efficiency in
typical use, where much time is spent doing less demanding tasks.[104]

With modern GPUs, energy usage is an important constraint on the maximum
computational capabilities that can be achieved. GPU designs are usually
highly scalable, allowing the manufacturer to put multiple chips on the same
video card, or to use multiple video cards that work in parallel. Peak
performance of any system is essentially limited by the amount of power it can
draw and the amount of heat it can dissipate. Consequently, performance per
watt of a GPU design translates directly into peak performance of a system
that uses that design.

Since GPUs may also be used for some [general purpose computation](/wiki/GPGPU
"GPGPU"), sometimes their performance is measured in terms also applied to
CPUs, such as FLOPS per watt.

integrated GPUs totaled around 75.5 million units, down 19% year-over-
year.
